THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
        v.
        Jessica P., Phil P., and Raymond B., Defendants,
        of whom Jessica P. and Raymond B. are Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal from Colleton County
 Robert S. Armstrong, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-197
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed May 1, 2007 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Robert J. Bonds, of Walterboro, for Appellant Raymond B.
        James G. Longtin, of Walterboro, for Appellant Jessica P.
        Mark S. Moore, of Walterboro, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:  This appeal arises from the termination of the parental rights of Raymond B. and Jessica P. to their minor children.  The family court terminated Raymond Bâ€™s rights to his son on two grounds: (1) willful failure to provide support and (2) the child has been in DSS custody for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.  Moreover, the family court terminated Jessica Pâ€™s rights to her minor children on the ground that they had been in DSS custody for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.  Further, the court found termination was in the best interest of the children.  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2006).
After a thorough review of the record pursuant to Ex Parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354 S.E.2d 381 (1987), we affirm the family courtâ€™s ruling terminating Jessica Pâ€™s and Raymond Bâ€™s parental rights on the grounds the child has been in DSS custody for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months  and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.[1]  See Charleston County Dept. of Social Services v. Jackson, 368 S.C. 87, 101, 627 S.E.2d 765, 773 (Ct. App. 2006) (noting that a child being in DSS custody for fifteen of the last twenty-two months alone is sufficient to support a termination of parental rights when in the best interest of the children).
AFFIRMED.[2]
STILWELL, SHORT and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Because we affirm the family court on this ground for termination, we need not address the issue of whether Raymond B. willfully failed to provide support.
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Lawrence W. Morris, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Colleton County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-198
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed May 1, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant. 
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; Solicitor I. McDuffie Stone, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Lawrence W. Morris appeals the imposition of restitution by the circuit court.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Morris and his brother entered an unoccupied but furnished home in the nighttime.Â  The home had been burgled sometime that day or in the previous week. Â While Morris was in the home, the police arrived.Â  Morris ran out the back door, leaving his vehicle in the yard. 
The State indicted Morris for â€œwillfully and unlawfully enter[ing] the dwelling of [the victim] without consent and with the intent to commit a crime therein . . . in the nighttime.â€Â  At a guilty plea hearing, Morris denied taking anything from the house and explained he was there to purchase drugs.Â  The trial court accepted his plea on that basis, stating: Â â€œThe crime does not have to be stealing but a crime. Â And youâ€™ve admitted to doing that so I will accept the guilty plea.â€Â  The court sentenced Morris to six years under the Youthful Offenders Act (YOA). Â 
Ten days later, a different judge presided over a restitution hearing.Â  Morris argued he should not have to pay restitution because he had not admitted to stealing any property.Â  The victim testified approximately $159,000 worth of personal property was missing from the house.Â  Morrisâ€™ ex-girlfriend testified Morris admitted breaking into a home. Â She further testified she saw numerous items at Morrisâ€™ house that she believed were stolen.Â  Morris did not admit to her that he stole the items. Â 
The trial court found it did not have to make a specific finding about the amount stolen or that â€œthe defendant stole each one of these itemsâ€ in order to impose restitution.Â  The court concluded Morris was involved in the theft of the property from the home and ordered Morris to pay $200 per month while on YOA parole, amounting to approximately $12,500. Â Morris appeals the restitution order.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Morris argues the trial court erred in ordering restitution because he did not admit to stealing any of the items and therefore his conviction did not support the award of restitution.Â  We disagree.Â  The trial judge has broad discretion in determining the manner, method, and amount of restitution.Â  State v. Cox, 326 S.C. 440, 442, 484 S.E.2d 108, 109 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  South Carolina Code Section 17-25-322 governs this issue and permits the trial court to take a number of things into account, including: Â 1) the financial resources of the defendant and the victim; 2) the ability of the defendant to pay restitution; 3) the anticipated rehabilitative effect on the defendant; 4) the effects on the victim of the defendantâ€™s criminal acts; and 5) the mental, physical, and financial well-being of the victim.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-322(B) (2003).Â  The judge must make specific findings of the underlying facts and circumstances on the record. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-322(C) (2003).
At the restitution hearing, the trial court heard the testimony of the defendant and the victim.Â  The court found: Â â€œfor purposes of this restitution hearing, [Morris] was involved in the theft of . . . items from that house . . . .â€Â  The court acknowledged the victim claimed losses of $159,000 and concluded it was not necessary to make a specific finding as to the value of items stolen.Â  The court considered Morrisâ€™ support obligation to his child, and other factors, and found Morris would be unable to pay restitution of $159,000.Â  The court thus ordered $200 per month during parole, totaling approximately $12,500.Â  We find the court sufficiently considered the statutory factors in imposing restitution and discern no abuse of discretion. Â 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        CompTrust AGC, f/k/a The Carolinas Associated General Contractors Workersâ€™Â Â  Compensation Self Insurance Trust Fund, Appellant/Respondent,
        v.
        Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. of Sumter and Whitakerâ€™s Trust, by and through its Trustees, Edsel V. Whitaker, Sr. and Edsel V. Whitaker of whom Whitakerâ€™s Inc. is Appellant
        and
        Whitakerâ€™s Trust is Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-199
Submitted April 10, 2007 â€“ Filed May 3, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Jerry Leo Finney and Richard C. Detwiler, both of Columbia, for Appellant-Respondent.
        Andrew Lindemann, of Columbia, for Appellant Whitakerâ€™s Inc.
        M.M. Weinberg, Jr., of Sumter, for Respondent Whitakerâ€™s Trust. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  CompTrust AGC (â€œCompTrustâ€) and Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. cross-appeal from a judgment in an action seeking to recover payment from an underlying workersâ€™ compensation case.Â  CompTrust contends the trial court erred in failing to extend the liability of Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. to Whitakerâ€™s Trust.Â  Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. contends the trial court erred in admitting evidence of a previous workersâ€™ compensation case and failing to instruct the jury on two requested charges.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
The Whitaker family runs Whitakerâ€™s, Inc., a company classified as a cabinet manufacturer for workersâ€™ compensation purposes.Â  The Whitaker family also maintains a trust, Whitakerâ€™s Trust, which is a separate entity set up by the Whitaker family purportedly for the benefit of the Mormon church.Â  Edsel Whitaker and his son Whit Whitaker are trustees.Â  In 1999, Whitakerâ€™s Trust owned approximately one hundred rental units, along with a farm, a warehouse, and the Mayesville plant, which Whitakerâ€™s Inc. leased from Whitakerâ€™s Trust.Â  Whitakerâ€™s Trust does not have any employees.Â  
Although classified as a cabinet manufacturer, Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. was used as a real estate management service for Whitakerâ€™s Trust.Â  Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. oversaw the management of Whitakerâ€™s Trust properties for a fee of $48,000 per year. 
Over the years, Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. also oversaw the construction of several apartment buildings for Whitakerâ€™s Trust.[2]Â  The Whitakers employed Judy Jernigan at various times over the course of ten years.Â  Jernigan is a friend of the Whitaker family, and began her working relationship with them on a contractual basis while employed full-time with a construction company.Â  In the early years, Jernigan worked for the Trust apartments.Â  She was paid in full by the Trust after completing odd jobs such as landscaping, cleaning around the apartments, getting the apartments ready to be shown to potential tenants, and painting a pool at one of the apartment complexes.Â  During the relevant period for purposes of this appeal, Jernigan was employed by Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. to work on an apartment project called Jernigan Trail.Â  Jernigan Trail is a twenty-four unit apartment building Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. constructed for Whitakerâ€™s Trust.Â  Jernigan performed various duties at the job site, including answering the phone, receiving and signing for deliveries, sending and receiving faxes, making sure that subcontractors showed up for work, and escorting various county inspectors out to the job site.Â  
On July 8, 1999, Jernigan was injured on this job site while using a lull to unload roof trusses from a delivery truck.Â  Subsequently, Jernigan filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim with CompTrust, Whitakerâ€™s Inc.â€™s workersâ€™ compensation carrier.Â  CompTrust listed Jernigan as a clerical employee.Â  CompTrust provided workersâ€™ compensation benefits to Jernigan; however, upon receiving Jerniganâ€™s claim for workersâ€™ compensation, CompTrust performed an investigation and determined that Jernigan was either not an employee of Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. or had been misclassified as a clerical employee.Â  CompTrust paid Jerniganâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation benefits and medical treatment under a â€œreservation of rights.â€Â  
CompTrust instituted this action, which included both legal and equitable claims, against Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. and Whitakerâ€™s Trust, seeking to recover funds it paid as a result of Jerniganâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  The jury returned a verdict in favor of CompTrust and against Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. for breach of contract, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, and negligent misrepresentation.Â  CompTrust was awarded $98,468.14 for reimbursement of workersâ€™ compensation benefits, $120,914.04 in total medical benefits, $15,952.00 in additional expenses, and $150,000.00 in punitive damages.Â  The trial court did not submit CompTrustâ€™s equitable claims against Whitakerâ€™s Trust to the jury.Â  Post trial, the trial court denied Whitakerâ€™s, Inc.â€™s motion for a new trial, granted Whitakerâ€™s, Inc.â€™sÂ  motion for a new trial nisi (reducing the additional expenses from $15,952.00 to $4,074.40), and denied CompTrustâ€™s equitable causes of action against Whitakerâ€™s Trust.Â  Both parties appeal.Â  
DISCUSSION
I.   CompTrust Appellate Issues 
As CompTrust frames the issues, its cause of action against Whitakerâ€™s Trust for equitable subrogation turns on whether Whitakerâ€™s Trust was either the de facto employer or statutory employer of Jernigan.[3]
Concerning the argument that Whitakerâ€™s Trust was the de facto employer of Jernigan, CompTrust cites no authority, case law or otherwise, to support this contention.Â  CompTrust merely refers to various dealings of the Whitakers and concludes that Whitakerâ€™s Trust â€œis nothing but a sham.â€Â  In the absence of citation to supporting legal authority, we must consider this issue abandoned.Â  See Fields v. Melrose Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 312 S.C. 102, 106 n.3, 439 S.E.2d 283, 285 n.3 (Ct. App. 1993) (stating issues raised in a brief but not supported by authority are deemed abandoned and will not be considered on appeal).
Turning to the statutory employment argument, we concur with the trial court that CompTrust has failed to prove Whitakerâ€™s Trust was the statutory employer of Jernigan.Â  
Section 42-1-400 of the South Carolina Code (1976) provides that an owner is liable to a worker of a contractor or subcontractor who is injured while performing or executing any work that is a part of the ownerâ€™s trade, business or occupation.Â  Specifically, this section states:

  When any person, in this section and 42-1-420 and 42-1-430 referred to as â€œowner,â€ undertakes to perform or execute any work which is a part of his trade, business or occupation and contracts with any other person (in this section and 42-1-420 to 42-1-450 referred to as â€œsubcontractorâ€) for the execution or performance by or under such subcontractor of the whole or any part of the work undertaken by such owner, the owner shall be liable to pay to any workman employed in the work any compensation under this Title which he would have been liable to pay if the workman had been immediately employed by him.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-400.Â  Whether a worker is a statutory employee is a question of law for the court.Â  Glass v. Dow Chem. Co., 325 S.C. 198, 202, 482 S.E.2d 49, 51 (1997).Â Â  Our courts have outlined three factors to consider when determining whether the activity constitutes work which is part of the ownerâ€™s trade, business, or occupation: (1) whether the activity is an important part of the trade or business, (2) whether the activity is a necessary, essential, and integral part of the trade, business or occupation, or (3) whether the activity has been performed by employees of the employer.Â  Id. at 201, 482 S.E.2d at 50.Â  
The evidence shows Whitakerâ€™s Trust hired Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. to perform both management and construction duties.Â  The record indicates Jernigan was hired to work mainly in construction, although she also had clerical duties.[4]Â  Jernigan was injured while performing her construction duties.Â  Therefore, the question we must determine is whether Whitakerâ€™s Trust was in the trade, business, or occupation of construction.Â  See Harrell v. Pineland Plantation, Ltd., 337 S.C. 313, 322, 523 S.E.2d 766, 771 (1999) (â€œ[A]n owner should not be able to avoid workersâ€™ compensation liability by subcontracting out the work of their business.â€).
The record is not clear on this critical issue.Â  It appears that at the time of Jerniganâ€™s injury, Whitakerâ€™s Trust owned about one hundred apartment units.Â  We are not certain how many of these units were constructed by Whitakerâ€™s Trust.Â  Part of our uncertainty is based on the evasive testimony given by the Whitakers.Â  Nevertheless, we feel it would be inappropriate to speculate by holding that construction was an important or integral part of the business of Whitakerâ€™s Trust. 
Whitakerâ€™s Trust, through its trustees, contracted work out to various professionals.Â  Here, Whitakerâ€™s Trust hired Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. to build apartments.Â  The evidence establishes that Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. employed Jernigan and that Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. was in the business of constructing residential dwellings.Â  The record does not establish that Whitakerâ€™s Trust was in the construction business; rather, Whitakerâ€™s Trust was the legal vehicle for holding title to various properties.Â  It was Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. that engaged in the construction and management oversight of the properties.Â  We fully recognize the improper conduct and gamesmanship of Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. vis-Ã -vis its workersâ€™ compensation policy with CompTrust, but this nefarious conduct does not warrant the leap that Whitakerâ€™s Trust is the statutory employer of Jernigan.Â  
A number of cases applying the Glass factors are analogous to the case at hand.Â  See Wilson v. Duke Power Co., 273 S.C. 610, 616-17, 258 S.E.2d 101, 104-05 (1979) (finding construction work performed for owner-developer of property was not part of his trade, business or occupation, and he was therefore not a statutory employer); see also Raines v. Gould, Inc., 288 S.C. 541, 543, 343 S.E.2d 655, 657 (Ct. App. 1986) (stating that ordinarily, in determining workersâ€™ compensation employee-employer relationship, construction work, such as building a factory structure or making electrical installations, is considered outside the trade or business of a manufacturer).Â Â  Nor may we discern from the record that this is a case where, by size and nature of its business, Whitakerâ€™s Trust is accustomed to carrying on a more or less ongoing program of construction.Â  See Raines, 288 S.C. at 545, 343 S.E.2d at 658 (â€œIf however a business by its size and nature is accustomed to carrying on a more or less ongoing program of construction . . . construction work delegated to a contractor may be considered a part of its trade or business.â€). Â 
In asserting the existence of a statutory employer relationship under section 42-1-400, CompTrust accepted the burden of setting forth evidence to prove its case.Â  We find, as did the trial court, that CompTrust has failed to meet its burden of showing Whitakerâ€™s Trust was in the trade, business, or occupation of construction under the Glass factors.Â  Because Whitakerâ€™s Trust is not in the business of construction, we find no error in the holding of the trial court that Jernigan was not a statutory employee of Whitakerâ€™s Trust.
II.  Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. Appellate Issues 
A. Â Admission of Evidence 
Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. contends the trial court erred in allowing into evidence the fact that another insurance company successfully sued Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. in a previous lawsuit for misclassifying employees for workersâ€™ compensation purposes.[5]Â  We disagree.Â  
The trial court has considerable latitude in ruling on the admissibility of a defendantâ€™s prior bad acts.Â  Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 155-56, 485 S.E.2d 903, 911 (1997).Â  Evidence is relevant and admissible if it tends to establish or make more or less probable some matter at issue and to bear directly or indirectly thereon.Â  Assoc. Mgt., Inc. v. E.D. Sauls Constr. Co., 279 S.C. 219, 221, 305 S.E.2d 236, 237 (1983).Â  Absent a clear abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law, the trial courtâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  Peterson v. Natâ€™l R.R. Passenger Corp., 365 S.C. 391, 399, 618 S.E.2d 903, 907 (2005).Â  
In finding the evidence relevant and admissible, the trial court cited Rule 404(b), SCRE, which governs the admissibility of â€œother crimes, wrongs, or acts.â€Â  The trial court reasoned that the information regarding the prior lawsuit was admissible to show Whitakerâ€™s, Inc.â€™s classification of Jernigan as a clerical employee was not the result of a mistake or accident, but rather showed intent to misclassify.Â  Rule 404(b) states:Â  

  Other Crimes, Wrongs, or Acts.Â  Evidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts is not admissible to prove the character of a person in order to show action in conformity therewith.Â  It may, however, be admissible to show motive, identity, the existence of a common scheme or plan, the absence of mistake or accident, or intent.[6]

 Even though such evidence may be relevant, it may be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice.Â  Rule 403, SCRE.Â  
At trial, one of the claims brought against Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. was for breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act.Â  To prove breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, a plaintiff must show, among other things, a fraudulent intent relating to the breaching of the contract. Â Floyd v. Country Squire Mobile Homes, Inc., 287 S.C. 51, 53-54, 336 S.E.2d 502, 503-04 (Ct. App. 1985). â€œFraudulent intent is normally proved by circumstances surrounding the breach.â€Â  Id. at 54, 336 S.E.2d at 503-04.
The record shows that Jernigan was misclassified as a clerical worker.Â  Whitakerâ€™s, Inc.â€™s claims to the contrary find no traction in this record.Â  Several witnesses, including Jernigan, testified Jernigan was misclassified as a clerical worker.Â  Whether Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. mistakenly or intentionally misclassified Jernigan was clearly relevant.Â  The measuring stick for Rule 403 admissibility is whether the probative value of the evidence is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice.Â  The trial court acted well within its discretion in admitting the prior lawsuit in which Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. misclassified an employee.Â  Moreover, the evidence against Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. on this issue was overwhelming even without evidence of the prior lawsuit.Â  
B.  Jury Charge 
Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. contends the trial court erred in failing to charge the jury regarding the laws and regulations concerning an employerâ€™s ability to stop payment of compensation benefits under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. sought these charges to show that CompTrust could have moved to stop payment to Jernigan once it had completed its investigation into the improper classification of Jernigan.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œWhen instructing the jury, the trial court is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.â€Â  Cohens v. Atkins, 333 S.C. 345, 349, 509 S.E.2d 286, 289 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œWhen a request to charge is timely made and involves a controlling legal principle, a refusal by the trial court to charge the request constitutes reversible error.â€Â  Brown v. Smalls, 325 S.C. 547, 555, 481 S.E.2d 444, 448 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  A jury charge that is substantially correct and covers the law does not require reversal.Â  Burroughs v. Worsham, 352 S.C. 382, 392, 574 S.E.2d 215, 220 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  When reviewing a jury charge for alleged error, the appellate court must consider the charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.Â  Daves v. Cleary, 355 S.C. 216, 224, 584 S.E.2d 423, 427 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œTo warrant reversal for refusal to give a requested instruction, the refusal must have not only been erroneous, but prejudicial as well.â€Â  Cohens, 333 S.C. at 349, 509 S.E.2d at 289.Â  
The first Request to Charge made by Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. comes from the case of Halks v. Rust Engâ€™g Co., 208 S.C. 39, 45-46, 36 S.E.2d 852, 855 (1946).Â  The request stemmed from a situation where a carrier disputed a claim under the theory that the claimant was no longer due compensation.Â  Specifically, Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. requested the trial court charge the following:Â  

  Rule 12 of the Commission contemplates that if the insurance carrier desires to stop further payment of compensation under a temporary award, application should be made to the Commission for permission to do so.Â  Notice should be given to the employee.Â  The question can then be determined by the Commission.Â  Where there is a disagreement between the parties as to the right to discontinue further weekly compensation, the matter will be placed on the calendar for a hearing.Â  If it is determined that the carrier is entitled to discontinue further payments of total temporary disability, the question of any permanent disability or disfigurement would then be ripe for determination.Â  But apart from the foregoing requirements we do not think the right of a claimant to further compensation can be adjudicated without notice to him and an opportunity afforded for a hearing, if he desires to contest the issue.

Additionally, the second Request to Charge involved the duties of the workersâ€™ compensation commission when a claimant is no longer due compensation.Â  It stated: 

  (F) After the one-hundred-fifty-day period has expired, the commission shall provide by regulation the method and procedure by which benefits may be suspended or terminated for any cause, but the regulation must provide for an evidentiary hearing and commission approval prior to termination or suspension unless such prior hearing is expressly waived in writing by the recipient or the circumstances identified in Section 42-9-260(B)(1) or (B)(2) are present.Â  Further, the commission may not entertain any application to terminate or suspend benefits unless and until the employer or carrier is current with all payments due.
  (B) Once temporary disability payments are commenced, the payments may be terminated or suspended immediately at any time within the one hundred fifty days if:
  (1) the employee has returned to work; however, if the employee does not remain at work for a minimum of fifteen days, temporary disability payments must be resumed immediately; or
  (2) the employee agrees that he is able to return to work and executes the proper commission form indicating that he is able to return to work.Â  

    See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-260(B) & (F) (Supp. 2006).Â  The trial court refused these requests and found that the subject matter of the requests was ancillary to the issues in the case, the law would only confuse the jury, and it would treat this issue as a matter of law after the jury determined the damages.Â  The trial court also found that the issue raised in the requested charges was not properly â€œframed by the pleadings.â€Â  
The issue of whether CompTrust should have moved to stop payment to Jernigan once it had completed its investigation into the improper classification of Jernigan constituted an affirmative defense that must have been specifically pled under Rule 8(c), SCRCP.Â  Because Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. failed to do so, and for the reasons stated by the trial court, there was no error in refusing these requests to charge.Â  
CONCLUSION
The judgment of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  There are numerous inconsistencies in the testimony concerning Whitakerâ€™s, Inc.Â Â  For example, Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. disputed the contention that Whitakerâ€™s, Inc. built apartments for Whitakerâ€™s Trust even though Whitakerâ€™s Trust acknowledged this fact it its brief.Â  The Whitakers also provided inconsistent testimony as to Judy Jerniganâ€™s role at Whitakerâ€™s, Inc.Â  
[3]Â  CompTrust seemingly raises this as two separate issues: equitable subrogation and restitution.Â  CompTrustâ€™s restitution claim, however, is merely a method of recovery for its equitable subrogation claim.Â  
[4]Â  The exact nature of Jerniganâ€™s job was, of course, a hotly contested issue at trial.Â  Our reading of the record leads us to believe Jernigan was hired to be the â€œproject managerâ€ of Jernigan Trail when Whit Whitaker could not be there.Â Â  
[5]Â  See Wassau v. Whitakerâ€™s, Inc., Op. No. 2001-UP-156 (filed February 7, 2001) (finding that the Defendant had attempted to avoid payment of workersâ€™ compensation premiums by classifying certain employees as â€œindependent contractorsâ€).Â  
[6]Â  The South Carolina rule limits the use of evidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts to those enumerated in State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).Â  See also Citizens Bank of Darlington v. McDonald, 202 S.C. 244, 252, 24 S.E.2d 369, 377 (1943) (finding Lyle applicable in civil cases).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        James Furtick, Appellant,
        v.
        South Carolina Department of Corrections, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 07-UP-200
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed May 3, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        James Furtick, of Bennettsville, pro se Appellant.Â  
        Nikole D. Haltiwanger, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  James Furtick appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order regarding access to his prison records pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (S.C. Code Ann. Section 30-4-10 et seq.).Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
As an inmate in the South Carolina Department of Corrections, Furtick filed a request with the Departmentâ€™s Director of Executive Affairs for â€œcopies ofâ€ his â€œcomplete prison recordâ€ . . . â€œfrom the year 1968 through the present, excluding medical records.â€Â  It is not clear from the record what correspondence was then exchanged between the parties, but an unsatisfied Furtick filed a complaint with the circuit court.Â  He also wrote to the Director of Executive Affairs inquiring about the lack of response to his request.Â  Furtick filed a motion for summary judgment, and that motion was heard on March 10, 2006.Â  
The circuit court issued an order stating that Furtickâ€™s â€œrequest was not sufficiently clear so that the SCDC could properly respond . . . .â€Â  The court provided that Furtick should have thirty days to submit a written request to the Department â€œspecifically identify[ing] the information which he is requesting . . . so that the SCDC will be able to determine the exact documents which [he] is requesting.â€Â  The courtâ€™s order further required Furtick to pay twenty-five cents per copy.Â  
Furtick raises several issues on appeal, alleging error on the part of the circuit court as follows:Â  (1) in determining that his FOIA request was not sufficiently clear, (2) in dismissing his claim when a motion to compel was pending, (3) in ruling Furtick had to purchase his prison records before he could inspect them, (4) in dismissing his case with prejudice, and (5) by not granting Furtickâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is appropriate when there are no genuine issues of material fact and the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56, SCRCP.Â  â€œSummary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.â€Â  Gadson v. Hembree, 364 S.C. 316, 320, 613 S.E.2d 533, 535 (2005).Â  â€œThe purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.â€Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Furtick first claims the court erred in finding that his request was not sufficiently clear.Â  We disagree.Â  At the hearing on Furtickâ€™s motion for summary judgment, the Department indicated there had been correspondence back and forth between Furtick and the Department regarding his request.Â  Furtick, while continuing to request his entire prison file, seemed to focus on obtaining information regarding his â€œwork creditsâ€ relating to the calculation of his release date.Â  According to the Department, Furtickâ€™s correspondence was â€œconfusingâ€ and requests for production filed by Furtick asked for information by generally referencing certain statutes, making it difficult to determine which documents would be responsive.Â  Based on this discussion, it appears Furtickâ€™s request was broad and lacked specificity.Â  Therefore, the courtâ€™s determination was not in error.
Furtick also claims the court erred in dismissing his motion for summary judgment when his motion to compel discovery was still pending.Â  As Furtick failed to move for a continuance or ask the court to hold its ruling on his summary judgment motion in abeyance, this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See Degenhart v. Knights of Columbus, 309 S.C. 114, 118, 420 S.E.2d 495, 497 (1992).
Furtick argues that it was error for the court to require that he pay for his records before he had the opportunity to inspect them. Â Section 30-4-30(a) of the South Carolina Code (Rev. 2007) provides â€œ[a]ny person has a right to inspect or copy any public record of a public body, except as otherwise provided by Â§ 30-4-40, in accordance with reasonable rules concerning time and place of access.â€Â  Nothing in the statute provides that records must be â€œsent toâ€ a person for inspection, and the statute does not mandate special consideration for inmates.Â  In addition, Furtick has the means to access the records he seeks.Â  He is simply required to make a sufficiently specific request and pay a fee for copying as provided by law.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-30(b) (Rev. 2007) (â€œThe public body may establish and collect fees not to exceed the actual cost of searching for or making copies of records.â€).[2]
Furtick further contends the court erred in denying his motion for summary judgment.Â  The denial of a motion for summary judgment is generally not appealable.Â  See Ballenger v. Bowen, 313 S.C. 476, 476, 443 S.E.2d 379, 380 (1994) (â€œThis Court has repeatedly held that the denial of summary judgment is not directly appealable.â€).Â  Consequently, this issue is not properly before us for review.Â  
Finally, Furtick contends the court erred in dismissing his claim with prejudice.Â  We disagree.Â  â€œA dismissal with prejudice acts as an adjudication on the merits and therefore precludes subsequent litigation just as if the action had been tried to a final adjudication.â€Â  Laughon v. Oâ€™Braitis, 360 S.C. 520, 527, 602 S.E.2d 108, 111 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The court heard from both Furtick and the Department, and the resulting order disposed of all the underlying matters in the suit.Â  Consequently, no purpose would be served by allowing Furtick to relitigate matters determined by the courtâ€™s order.Â  Should either side not comply with the courtâ€™s mandate, the aggrieved party can file a rule to show cause regarding the other partyâ€™s failure to comply with the order.
Based on all of the foregoing, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â The standard charge imposed by the Department for copying is twenty-five cents per page.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Laura Johnson Young and Eldon Johnson Thomas, Respondents,
        v.
        Eldora J. Lock, Sam Erskine Johnson, Pearlie Mae Johnson Gray, Brenda Johnson Downs, 
          Milford Anthony Johnson, Helen Johnson Evans, Herbert J. Goodjoins, Jr., Amy Johnson 
          Bivens, Helen Bruce Johnson a/k/a Helen Bruce Johnson Goodjoins, Billy Johnson, Melvin 
          Douglas Johnson, Barbara Johnson, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Minnie 
          Johnson, Jr., David V. Johnson, Brenda Lee Johnson McCarroll, Elizabeth M. Johnson a/k/a 
          Michelle Johnson Sullivan, Eldon Ann Thompson a/k/a Eldon J. Thomas, Karetha Johnson, 
          Carol J. Johnson, Calvin Boyd Johnson, Jr., Della Clark Johnson, Laura Johnson Young, 
          and all other persons whose identity is unknown who claim any right, title, or interest 
          under or through any of the above named Defendants as heirs, devisees or creditors, all 
          such persons being designated as a class John Doe, and all such persons being under a 
          legal disability or in the Armed Services of the United States of America being designated 
          as a class Richard Roe, Defendants,
        of whom Eldon Ann Thompson, a/k/a Eldon J. Thomas, and Barbara Johnson, as 
          Personal Representative of the Estate of Minnie Johnson, Jr., are the Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens County
W. Reid Cox, Jr., Special Referee 

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-202
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed May 4, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Laâ€™Keabian D. Shaw, of Fountain Inn, for Appellants.
        James E. Bryan, Jr. and Thomas J. Thompson, both of Laurens, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Laura Johnson Young (â€œRespondent Youngâ€) and Eldon Johnson Thomas (â€œAppellant Thomasâ€) originally brought this partition action as plaintiffs seeking the sale of real property.Â  An Order for Default was entered and the matter was transferred to a special referee, who ordered the property to be sold after finding it could not be divided in kind.Â  Appellant Thomas belatedly tried to oppose the partition by sale, arguing the property could, instead, be divided in kind, and she attempted to change her Â position from a plaintiff to a defendant.Â  Appellant Thomas has now joined with one of the defendants, Minnie Johnson, Jr. (â€œAppellant Johnsonâ€), and together Appellants challenge the orders of the referee.[1]Â  We affirm.[2]Â  
FACTS
This partition action involves two tracts of property located in Laurens County, South Carolina.Â  Tract One is approximately five acres; Tract Two is 70.4 acres.Â  The property was acquired in the 1950s by Minnie Johnson, Sr. and his wife, Pearlie Mae Johnson.Â  The parties to this action are their descendants.Â  Respondent Young and Appellant Thomas are two of their daughters, and Appellant Johnson is one of their sons.
Minnie Johnson, Sr. died intestate on July 25, 1983, leaving as his heirs at law his wife, eleven living children, and a predeceased son who was survived by three children.Â  Upon her husbandâ€™s death, Pearlie Mae Johnson owned a two-thirds interest in the two tracts and the remaining interest was held in various proportions by their eleven living children and the three children of their deceased son.Â  Â Â 
On February 18, 1993, Pearlie Mae Johnson died testate, specifically devising her interest in a residence and the five-acre Tract One to Respondent Young, subject to a life estate to be held by one of Pearlie Maeâ€™s grandsons as long as he met certain terms and conditions.Â  These terms and conditions were not met, however, and this circumstance, along with other factors, caused the ownership of both tracts of land to come into question.[3]Â  
On January 25, 2005, Respondent Young and Appellant Thomas filed this partition action.Â  They alleged the property could not be divided in kind and requested a judicial sale instead, with the proceeds to be divided among the parties according to their ownership interests.Â  A circuit court judge appointed a guardian ad litem to represent the interests of the unknown defendants, designated as John Doe and Richard Roe.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Five months later, an Order for Default was filed on June 29, 2005 after none of the defendants responded to the complaint.Â  On the same date, an Order of Reference was issued, transferring the action to a referee.Â  Â Â Â Â 
The referee held a hearing on October 10, 2005 attended by Respondent Young (as plaintiff) and several defendants, including Appellant Johnson.Â  Appellant Thomas, the other named plaintiff in the action, did not attend the hearing.Â  Before the decision to sell the property was formally made, however, the referee discovered the unknown defendants, John Doe and Richard Roe, could not be located for proper service, and the referee ordered service by publication in a ruling dated October 10, 2005.[4]Â  Issuance of the final order was delayed until service was completed.Â  
In the meantime, a dispute arose between Respondent Young and Appellant Thomas concerning the feasibility of dividing the subject property.Â  On October 16, 2005, Appellant Thomas notified her attorneys, who also represented Respondent Young, that she no longer wished to be represented by them.Â Â Â  
Appellant Thomas retained new counsel and belatedly joined with her brother, Appellant Johnson (a named defendant), in asking the court not to sell the property.Â  Specifically, on November 10, 2005, Appellants filed an Answer and Counterclaim opposing a sale of the property and seeking, instead, a partition in kind.Â  On the same day, Laâ€™Keabian D. Shaw filed a Notice of Representation, stating she now represented Appellants.Â Â Â  Appellant Johnson had not previously filed an answer to the complaint in this action, and this filing came more than four months after the filing of the Order for Default and a month after his attendance at the merits hearing.Â  In addition, no court order was requested or obtained by Appellant Thomas authorizing the substitution of counsel or the alteration of her status as a plaintiff.Â  On December 8, 2005, Appellants also filed an Amended Answer and Counterclaim.Â  The primary difference between the two versions is that the amended pleading asserted service of process was insufficient as to Appellant Thomas.Â Â Â  
On December 14, 2005, the special referee issued his formal, written ruling in the matter determining the interests of the parties and ordering a sale of both Tract One and Tract Two.Â  The same day, Appellant Thomas prepared an Amended Complaint, requesting the dismissal of the complaint pursued by Respondent Young.Â  She also requested a partition in kind, asserting the property could be divided and should not be sold.Â  It is not clear from the record whether the Amended Complaint was ever served.
The referee thereafter issued an order on December 16, 2005, finding the filing of subsequent pleadings, specifically the Answer and Counterclaim and the Amended Answer and Counterclaim, was improper.Â  The referee stated all of the named defendants in this action had either accepted service of the original pleadings or were personally served, and the unknown defendants were served by publication.Â  In addition, Appellant Thomas was one of the two named plaintiffs when the action commenced and she still remained a plaintiff until removed by order of the court, so she could not file responsive pleadings as a defendant.Â  The referee stated Appellant Thomas could not litigate this action by being both a plaintiff and a defendant.Â  Since Appellant Thomas was and remained a plaintiff, there was no requirement that she be served with the pleadings, and Appellant Johnson was duly served and was in default and therefore he could not now file responsive pleadings.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A partition action is an equitable action heard by a judge alone; therefore, upon review an appellate court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Anderson v. Anderson, 299 S.C. 110, 113, 382 S.E.2d 897, 899 (1989).Â  While this permits us a broad scope of review, we do not, however, disregard the findings of the special referee, who saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate their credibility.Â  See, e.g., Klutts Resort Realty, Inc. v. Downâ€™Round Dev. Corp., 268 S.C. 80, 91, 232 S.E.2d 20, 26 (1977).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Amended ComplaintÂ  
Appellants first contend the â€œreferee erred in not allowing Appellant Thomas to amend her complaint.â€Â  
Rule 15(a), SCRCP outlines the following procedure for amending a pleading:

  A party may amend his pleading once as a matter of course at any time before or within 30 days after a responsive pleading is served . . . .Â  Otherwise a party may amend his pleading only by leave of court or by written consent of the adverse party . . . .

â€œA motion to amend is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial judge, and the party opposing the motion has the burden of establishing prejudice.â€Â  Kelly v. S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 316 S.C. 319, 323, 450 S.E.2d 59, 61 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  â€œThe prejudice Rule 15 envisions is a lack of notice that the new issue is going to be tried, and a lack of opportunity to refute it.â€Â  Pool v. Pool, 329 S.C. 324, 328-29, 494 S.E.2d 820, 823 (1998), quoted in Tanner v. Florence County Treasurer, 336 S.C. 552, 559, 521 S.E.2d 153, 156 (1999).
Appellants contend Appellant Thomasâ€™s Amended Complaint dated December 14, 2005 should have been allowed because it was allegedly filed less than thirty days after a responsive pleading was filed.Â  On November 10, 2005, Appellants jointly filed an Answer and Counterclaim asserting the subject property could be equitably divided among the parties and should not be sold.Â  They filed an Amended Answer and Counterclaim on December 8, 2005.Â  When these responsive pleadings were filed, however, Appellant Johnson was already in default and Appellant Thomas was still one of the two named plaintiffs in the case.Â  Therefore, the responsive pleadings Appellants now rely on were improper on their face.
While Rule 21, SCRCP does permit an existing plaintiff to become a defendant, this change generally must be accomplished by motion served on the opposing parties and approved by court order.Â  Appellant Thomasâ€™s Amended Complaint may have been allowed only pursuant to a motion to amend, which was never filed.Â  Consequently, there can be no error in this regard.[5]
II. Answer and Counterclaim 
Appellants next contend the â€œreferee erred in dismissing the Answer and Counterclaim filed by Appellant Minnie Johnson, Jr.â€Â  They argue the pleading was timely because the Order for Default was obtained based on an affidavit that incorrectly stated all of the defendants had been served and the pleading was filed before the completion of service by publication.
In declining to allow the belated filing of responsive pleadings, the referee concluded Appellant Johnson â€œwas duly and legally served with the pleadings and was in default when the matter was heard and therefore [he] cannot now file responsive pleadings.â€Â  We find no error in the refereeâ€™s determination.Â  
The complaint in this case was filed with the Clerk of the Laurens County Court on January 25, 2005.Â  The Order for Default was filed on June 29, 2005.Â  Appellant Johnson attended the hearing on the merits in this matter on October 10, 2005; however, he did not attempt to file responsive pleadings in the case until November 10, 2005, which was a month after the hearing in the matter, more than four months after the filing of the Order for Default, and nearly ten months after the filing of the original complaint.Â  Â Â 
In her brief, Respondent Young admits there was an error in the original affidavit requesting the entry of default to the extent it stated all defendants had been served when in fact, all of the named defendants had been served, but the unknown defendants had not been served by publication.Â  In light of this circumstance, the referee did not issue his final order until service by publication addressed to the unknown defendants was completed.Â  Â Â 
The record contains an affidavit of service from a process server stating Appellant Johnson was served with a copy of the complaint on April 30, 2005.Â  The referee specifically found in his final order filed December 14, 2005 that Appellant Johnson had been â€œpersonally served with the [complaint].â€Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the refereeâ€™s determination that Appellant Johnson failed to file a responsive pleading in this case for more than thirty days after receiving service of the complaint.Â  Appellant Johnson was, therefore, in default when he belatedly filed his responsive pleading in November 2005, and the referee did not err in excluding the pleading on the basis it was untimely.Â  
III. Ethical Violations of Counsel 
Appellants assert they â€œshould be relieved from the orders of the special refereeâ€ due to the fact that â€œcounsel for Respondent Young also represented Appellant Thomas in this matter now on appeal.â€Â  They argue Respondent Young and Appellant Thomas had competing interests because Respondent Young sought a partition by sale on the basis a partition in kind was not possible, whereas Appellant Thomas disagreed and desired a partition in kind.Â  Appellants contend counselâ€™s representation violated the Rules of Professional Conduct, particularly Rule 1.9(a) of Rule 407, SCACR, which states:Â  â€œA lawyer who has formerly represented a client in a matter shall not thereafter represent another person in the same or a substantially related matter in which that personâ€™s interests are materially adverse to the interests of the former client unless the former client gives informed consent, confirmed in writing.â€Â  
This issue has not been preserved for our review as there is no evidence in the record that the issue was ever both raised to and ruled on by the special referee; rather, it appears to be asserted for the first time on appeal.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  This court is not the appropriate forum to either institute a disciplinary matter or allege a new civil action.Â  
IV. Order of ReferenceÂ  
Appellants lastly assert the Order of Reference should be set aside because the order was entered before the unknown defendants John Doe and Richard Roe were served by publication.Â  
This allegation was not preserved for our review.Â  Appellants did not assert this issue before the referee and have raised it for the first time on appeal.Â  In fact, Appellant Thomas was still maintaining her status as a plaintiff at the time the Order of Reference was issued and it was actually her attorney who moved for the default judgment and the Order of Reference that she now, belatedly, seeks to invalidate. Â See Wilder Corp., 330 S.C. at 76, 497 S.E.2d at 733 (holding an issue that is not both raised to and ruled upon by the trial court is not preserved for appeal).Â  
AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Appellant Johnson died while this appeal was pending and a personal representative appears on his behalf.Â  For simplicity, we shall refer to Appellant Johnson directly as the party.
[2]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] Pearlie Mae Johnsonâ€™s will provided one of her grandsons, Herbert J. Goodjoins, Jr., was to have the residence and Tract One for use during his lifetime as long as he occupied the property, maintained adequate insurance coverage, paid the taxes, and kept the property in good repair.Â  The will further provided if Goodjoins failed to abide by these terms and conditions, died, or no longer desired to live on the property, Pearlie Mae Johnsonâ€™s interest in the home and Tract One was to be transferred to Respondent Young in fee simple.Â  The referee found Goodjoins failed to maintain the property as required by the will, resulting in Pearlie Mae Johnsonâ€™s interest going to Respondent Young in fee simple.Â  We note Goodjoinsâ€™s last name also appears in the record as Goodjohn, but the former version appears in the captions of the orders on appeal so it is retained here.Â Â Â  
[4] Â Service by publication was completed on October 26, 2005.Â  Â Â 
[5]Â  There is a question, moreover, regarding whether the referee expressly ruled on this issue.Â  In his order of December 16, 2005 the referee found Appellantsâ€™ belated filing of an Answer and Counterclaim and an Amended Answer and Counterclaim was improper.Â  The referee did not specifically discuss Appellant Thomasâ€™s Amended Complaint.Â  Counsel for Appellants sent a letter to the referee asking him to amend the December 16, 2005 order to rule on this issue, but there is nothing further in the record on this point.Â  In any event, there is no merit to this issue because there is no indication in the record that Appellant Thomas timely moved for permission to file the Amended Complaint as required by the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Lareese Glover, Appellant,
        v.
        Albert A. Glover and Dorchester County Delinquent Tax Collector, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Â Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-207
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed May 9, 2007

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        John J. Pinckney, of Bluffton, for Appellant.
        Jennifer L. Queen and John G. Frampton, both of Summerville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Lareese Glover (â€œGloverâ€) brought this action against her brother Albert A. Glover (â€œAlbertâ€) and the Dorchester County Delinquent Tax Collector (â€œTax Collectorâ€) to set aside a tax deed issued to Albert, to recognize a constructive trust, and to confirm a prescriptive easement.Â  The circuit court dismissed the complaint for lack of standing and failure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action as provided by Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  Glover appeals.Â  We reverse and remand.[1]
FACTS
The following facts are taken from Gloverâ€™s amended complaint and, under our standard of review, are presumed to be true for purposes of evaluating whether the complaint states a claim for relief.Â  The property at issue consists of approximately 5.9 acres located in Dorchester County, South Carolina.Â  Part of the acreage has been used for a softball field for members of the nearby Pigeon[2] Bay Community, and Glover has operated a concession stand on the property since 1981.Â  Â Â 
There is no continuous chain of title for the subject property in the Dorchester County real estate records.Â  It appears the property was part of a tract of land conveyed by deed dated June 29, 1920, from William H. Johnston et al. to Thomas Glover, an uncle of Glover and Albert.Â  Thomas died in the 1940s, and the property was thereafter placed in the name of his surviving wife, Daisey Glover, as they had no children.Â  After Daisey died intestate around 1960, Thomasâ€™s brother, Samuel Glover, paid the taxes on the property for the benefit of the Pigeon Bay Community until his death in 1997.Â  Samuel is the father of Glover and her brother Albert.Â  Â Â 
Glover further alleges that after the death of her father, Samuel, in 1997, his children[3] paid the real estate taxes on the property each year for the benefit of the Pigeon Bay Community.Â  She asserted â€œthe [p]roperty â€˜passedâ€™ by custom, over time, in a gradual and informal way into the hands of Samuel Glover in trust for the benefit of the entire Pigeon Bay Community.â€Â  According to Glover, the property â€œhas been dedicated for the use of the [Pigeon] Bay Community in general for recreation, and it was improved and used as a community softball field from time immemorial.â€Â  Glover stated that, with the consent of her father, Samuel, and the Pigeon Bay Community, in 1981 â€œshe began to have exclusive use of an area of the [p]ropertyâ€ to run a concession stand.Â  
In the meantime, the property remained indexed and listed in the name of Daisey Glover. Â At some point, Albert contacted the Tax Collector regarding the subject property and asked that the address for tax bills be changed to his address.Â  In 2002, the Tax Collector mailed a notice of delinquent taxes on the property for the year 2001 to â€œGlover Daisey c/o Albert Glover 344 Pigeon Bay Road Summerville, SC 29483.â€Â  
The Tax Collector sold the property to Albert on October 7, 2002.Â  On March 5, 2004, the Tax Collector executed a tax deed conveying the property to Albert as the sole owner.Â  A legal description of the property was included in the deed, along with the following notation:Â  â€œNo derivation on record.â€Â  
Glover brought this action against Albert and the Tax Collector in 2005, alleging claims for (1) fraud in the procurement of a tax deed, (2) constructive trust, and (3) a prescriptive easement.[4]Â  Glover essentially alleged that her family paid the real estate taxes on the property for many years until her brother Albert contacted the Tax Collector and had the address for sending tax notices changed so that the notices would be sent to him.Â  Glover contended Albert thereafter failed to pay the taxes and then purchased the property at a tax sale, thus depriving Glover and others of their interests in the property.Â  Glover asserted Albertâ€™s bidding at the tax sale was fraudulently done to obtain a clear title to the property in violation of the rights of his cotenants.Â  The circuit court dismissed the complaint in its entirety as to both Albert and the Tax Collector.Â  Glover appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA motion to dismiss a claim pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, must be based solely on the allegations set forth on the face of the complaint.â€Â  Overcash v. S.C. Elec. & Gas Co., 364 S.C. 569, 572, 614 S.E.2d 619, 620 (2005).Â  â€œThe motion will not be sustained if the facts alleged and the inferences reasonably deducible therefrom would entitle the plaintiff to relief on any theory of the case.â€Â  Id.Â  
â€œ[A] judgment on the pleadings is considered to be a drastic procedure by our courts.â€Â  Russell v. City of Columbia, 305 S.C. 86, 89, 406 S.E.2d 338, 339 (1991); see also United Educ. Distribs., LLC v. Educ. Testing Serv., 350 S.C. 7, 13, 564 S.E.2d 324, 328 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œTherefore, pleadings in a case should be construed liberally and the Court must presume all well pled facts to be true so that substantial justice is done between the parties.â€Â  Overcash, 364 S.C. at 572, 614 S.E.2d at 620.Â   
    LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Standing
On appeal, Glover first contends the circuit court erred in granting the motion to dismiss because she did not have standing to maintain her suit.
â€œStanding to sue is a fundamental requirement in instituting an action.â€Â  
    Joytime Distribs. & Amusement Co. v. State, 338 S.C. 634, 639, 528 S.E.2d 647, 649 (1999).Â  â€œGenerally, a party must be a real party in interest to the litigation to have standing.â€Â  Sloan v. Friends of the Hunley, Inc., 369 S.C. 20, 28, 630 S.E.2d 474, 479 (2006).Â  â€œA real party in interest is one who has a real, material, or substantial interest in the subject matter of the action, as opposed to one who has only a nominal or technical interest in the action.â€Â  Charleston County Sch. Dist. v. Charleston County Elec. Commâ€™n, 336 S.C. 174, 181, 519 S.E.2d 567, 571 (1999) (citation omitted).
To have standing, a plaintiff must establish (1) prejudice from a particularized injury that is not merely a matter of general interest common to all members of the public; (2) a causal connection between the injury and the conduct complaint of; and (3) a likelihood, as opposed to speculation, that the injury will be redressed by a favorable decision.Â  Sea Pines Assâ€™n for the Prot. of Wildlife, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Res. & Cmty. Servs. Assocs., 345 S.C. 594, 600-01, 550 S.E.2d 287, 291 (2001).
As a threshold matter, the circuit court found Gloverâ€™s action should be dismissed for lack of standing because she â€œhas failed to satisfy her burden of demonstrating a particularized harm sufficient to justify maintaining this law suit.â€Â  The court stated Glover alleged that both she and Albert, together with other members of the Pigeon Bay Community, held â€œbeneficial titleâ€ to the property through the actions of their father, Samuel Glover, and the transfer of the tax deed was improper because the property was held in a constructive trust for the benefit of members of the Pigeon Bay Community.Â  Â Â 
The court remarked, â€œ[Gloverâ€™s] standing appears to arise out of her claim that she is a â€˜residentâ€™ of this Community.Â  [Glover] fails, however, to allege any particular injury either she or the Community has suffered as a result of [Albert] holding the title to this Property.Â  [Glover] also fails to demonstrate a causal connection between [Albertâ€™s] actions and any injury whatsoever; and, although she does ask that the deed be voided, she does not address how this outcome redresses any injury.â€Â Â Â  
In examining the four corners of Gloverâ€™s amended complaint, which is all we are concerned with at this preliminary stage in the proceedings, we find her allegations are sufficient to confer standing.Â  Although Glover admittedly had some apparent contradictions[5] in her pleadings, Glover did allege that she and Albert were co-owners or cotenants and that Albert had fraudulently procured a tax deed in order to establish clear title to the property and become the sole owner, thus depriving her of her interest in the property in running a concession stand.Â  In addition, Glover alleged she and the other members of the Pigeon Bay Community were deprived of their interests in seeing the property maintained for public use as a softball field and recreation area.Â  Thus, we hold Glover has standing to proceed as she has alleged a particularized injury, i.e., that she was being deprived of both her right to run the concession stand and her ownership interest in the property, and she has alleged a causal connection between Albertâ€™s procurement of the tax deed and her resulting injury.Â  
II.Â  Failure to State a Cause of Action
Glover next contends the circuit court erred in dismissing all of her claims for failure to state a cause of action under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.
A.Â  Fraud in the Procurement of a Tax Deed 
As noted by the circuit court, the Supreme Court of South Carolina recognized a cause of action for fraud in the procurement of a tax deed in Matthews v. Montgomery, 193 S.C. 118, 7 S.E.2d 841 (1940).Â  In Matthews, the plaintiff alleged the defendant fraudulently arranged for the defendantâ€™s son to purchase the defendantâ€™s property at a tax sale in order to place it out of the reach of the plaintiff and other potential creditors.Â  Id. at 128-29, 7 S.E.2d at 846. Â At the time the tax deed was procured, the plaintiff had filed a lawsuit against the defendant for a debt, and judgment in favor of the plaintiff was imminent.Â  Id. at 129, 7 S.E.2d at 846.Â  
Our supreme court stated it was necessary â€œto differentiate between attacking the deeds for alleged fraud . . . and attacking them for alleged irregularities in the tax sale and proceedings.â€Â  Id. at 128, 7 S.E.2d at 846.Â  The court observed no fraud was alleged on the part of the tax collector, and the regularity of the governmental tax procedure â€œis no more of an obstacle to a suit to set aside the deeds for fraud than would the regularity and legality in form and execution of a conveyance by voluntary act of the parties interpose a shield which would protect it from attack if the requisites of fraudulent intent are present.â€[6]Â  Id. at 131, 7 S.E.2d at 847.Â  The court concluded the plaintiffâ€™s complaint asserted a claim for fraud in the procurement of a tax deed.Â  Id. at 134, 7 S.E.2d at 848.
In the current case, the circuit court, citing Matthews, among others, stated, â€œAlthough limited in number, the cases in which South Carolina courts have addressed fraud in the procurement of a tax deed all arise out of a creditor seeking recovery for fraudulent conveyance.â€Â  The court noted Glover â€œis not a creditor, [Albert] is not a debtor, and no property has been transferred to avoid a debt.Â  As such, this cause of action should be dismissed.â€Â  Â Â 
We find no language in Matthews that purports to limit its application to creditors.Â  Moreover, the circuit court pointed to no specific cases expressly limiting the application of the claim in this manner.Â  The fact that fraud in the procurement of a tax deed was originally applied in a case involving the rights of creditors does not prevent its application in other factual situations.Â  Cf. Boyd v. BellSouth Tel. Telegraph Co., 369 S.C. 410, 420, 633 S.E.2d 136, 141 (2006) (stating â€œ[r]egardless of whether an easement implied by prior use was originally recognized in a water drainage situation, this does not prevent its application in other circumstancesâ€).Â  
In addition, we find dismissal is not appropriate because there are competing inferences arising from the allegations in the complaint, such as whether Glover was a cotenant, a co-owner, or an heir.Â  See Jensen v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 297 S.C. 323, 334, 377 S.E.2d 102, 108 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œ[W]here the allegations of the complaint give rise to competing inferences on a question of material fact, dismissal of the case under Rule 12(b)(6) is not appropriate.â€).Â  Accordingly, we reverse the dismissal of Gloverâ€™s claim for fraud in the procurement of a tax deed.
B.Â  Constructive Trust
â€œA constructive trust will arise whenever the circumstances under which property was acquired make it inequitable that it should be retained by the one holding the legal title.â€Â  Lollis v. Lollis, 291 S.C. 525, 529, 354 S.E.2d 559, 561 (1987).Â  â€œA constructive trust results from fraud, bad faith, abuse of confidence, or violation of a fiduciary duty which gives rise to an obligation in equity to make restitution.â€Â  Id. (citing Searson v. Webb, 208 S.C. 453, 38 S.E.2d 654 (1946)).Â  â€œFraud is an essential element, although it need not be actual fraud.â€Â  Id. 
In asserting her claim for a constructive trust, Glover alleged (1) the property â€œha[d] been dedicated for the use of the [Pigeon] Bay Community in general for recreation, and it was improved and used as a community softball field from time immemorialâ€; (2) in 1981 Glover began to have exclusive use of a portion of the property to run a concession stand with the consent of Samuel Glover and the Pigeon Bay Community; (3) Glover and Albert â€œare members of the [Pigeon] Bay Community and hold beneficial title interests in the [p]roperty by and t[h]rough the actions taken by their father, Samuel Glover, for the benefit of the Pigeon Bay Communityâ€; and (4) the tax deed transferring the property to Albert is improper because any acquisition by Albert â€œinured to the members of the [Pigeon] Bay Community under a constructive trust.â€Â  
The circuit court noted â€œ[t]he only allegations of the existence of a fiduciary relationship are unclear references to the parties being â€˜co-tenants.â€™Â  [Glover] alleged that [Albert], as a co-owner, breached this duty by buying the [p]roperty at the tax sale.â€Â  The court based its dismissal of Gloverâ€™s claim for a constructive trust on its finding â€œco-tenants generally owe no duty to each other as to property taxes absent a contractual agreement; each co-tenant is responsible for paying taxes with a right of contribution from the others.â€Â  The court further found that, â€œ[e]ven assuming [Glover and Albert] were co-tenants at some time in the past, such relationship would have ended when [Glover] took sole possession of the concession stand in 1980 [sic] . . . .â€Â  
In her amended complaint, Glover essentially alleged Albert committed fraud in obtaining the property at the tax sale by representing to the Tax Collector that he was a bona fide purchaser for value when in fact he was a co-owner of the property.Â  Glover further alleged Albert, as a co-owner, contacted the Tax Collector and changed the address for tax notices so that the notices would be sent to him, and then he intentionally allowed the property to lapse so that he could clear any other claims to the property by purchasing it at the tax sale in his name only.Â  
We hold these allegations of fraud are sufficient to state a claim for a constructive trust.Â  â€œA constructive trust arises against one who by fraud, actual or constructive, by duress or abuse of confidence, by commission of a wrong or by any form of unconscionable conduct, artifice, concealment, or questionable means and against good conscience, either has obtained or holds the right to property which he ought not in equity and good conscience hold and enjoy.â€ Â Halbersberg v. Berry, 302 S.C. 97, 106, 394 S.E.2d 7, 13 (Ct. App. 1990) (emphasis added).
Although the circuit court focused on whether Glover had properly alleged a fiduciary relationship, we find she did assert fraud, which is a basis on which to impose a constructive trust.Â  See Lollis, 291 S.C. at 529, 354 S.E.2d at 561 (â€œA constructive trust results from fraud, bad faith, abuse of confidence, or violation of a fiduciary duty which gives rise to an obligation in equity to make restitution.â€ (emphasis added)); Searson, 208 S.C. at 459, 38 S.E.2d at 657 (â€œA constructive trust, unlike an express trust, is not a fiduciary relation, although the circumstances which give rise to a constructive trust may or may not involve a fiduciary relation[.]â€ (citation omitted) (emphasis added)).Â  Thus, we reverse the dismissal of Gloverâ€™s claim for a constructive trust.Â  Cf. Searson, 208 S.C. at 461-62, 38 S.E.2d at 659 (holding, construing the pleadings liberally, the plaintiff sufficiently alleged a claim for a constructive trust against her first cousin where the two orally agreed to purchase property jointly, but the defendant thereafter obtained title in his own name without the plaintiffâ€™s knowledge).
C.Â  Prescriptive Easement
To set forth a claim for a prescriptive easement, a party must establish:Â  (1) the continued and uninterrupted use or enjoyment of the right for a period of twenty years, (2) the identity of the thing enjoyed, and (3) the use must have been adverse or under a claim of right.Â  Horry County v. Laychur, 315 S.C. 364, 367, 434 S.E.2d 259, 261 (1993); see also Jones v. Daley, 363 S.C. 310, 316, 609 S.E.2d 597, 599-600 (Ct. App. 2005).
In her amended complaint, Glover alleged that she has an easement by prescription to operate a concession stand on the property because she has exclusively operated the concession stand at community softball games for more than twenty years, the stand is clearly identified by an existing structure on the property, and she was using the property under a valid claim of right.Â  Glover averred she â€œbelieved that her use of the [p]roperty was a right given to her by family members as heirs of an owner of the [p]roperty or, alternatively, that her use was a right being claimed by her as a member of the class of beneficiaries for whom the subject [property] was being held in trust.â€Â Â Â  
The circuit court ruled Gloverâ€™s first source for a claim of right failed as a matter of law because she â€œalso specifically alleges that she and her brother are not â€˜heirsâ€™â€ and â€œ[n]o right can arise from the grant of an heir when there are no heirs.â€Â  As to the second source for a claim of right, i.e., a beneficial interest, the court ruled Glover and her brother both would hold a beneficial interest according to the complaint, and they could not hold a beneficial interest along with other members of the Pigeon Bay Community and have a claim of right sufficient to satisfy the elements for a prescriptive easement.Â  
We hold Gloverâ€™s allegations satisfy the pleading requirements at this stage to set forth a cause of action for a prescriptive easement as she has alleged a continuous and uninterrupted use of the property to operate a concession stand for twenty years, the stand is clearly identifiable, and she has used the property under an asserted claim of right.Â  Although Glover did allege at one point she was not an heir of Daisy Glover, she also alleged she and her brother were co-owners of the property and she had acquired a right to the property through family members who were heirs.Â  In addition, the fact that others also had a beneficial interest in the property does not affect the sufficiency of the pleadings.Â  Consequently, we reverse the dismissal of the claim for a prescriptive easement.Â  See Russell, 305 S.C. at 89, 406 S.E.2d at 339 (â€œWhen a fact is well pleaded, any inference of law or conclusions of fact that may properly arise therefrom are to be regarded as embraced in the averment.â€); id. (â€œMoreover, a complaint is sufficient if it states any cause of action or it appears that the plaintiff is entitled to any relief whatsoever.â€). 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we conclude Glover does have standing to bring this action and her complaint sufficiently alleges the elements of her claims for (1) fraud in the procurement of a tax deed, (2) the imposition of constructive trust, and (3) the existence of a prescriptive easement.Â  Consequently, the order directing the dismissal of Gloverâ€™s complaint for lack of standing and the failure to properly state her claims is
REVERSED AND REMANDED.[7]
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  â€œPigeonâ€ also appears as â€œPidgeonâ€ in some of the documents in the Record on Appeal referring to the Pigeon Bay Community and nearby Pigeon Bay Road.Â  For consistency, we shall use the former spelling.
[3]Â  Glover is one of eight children born to Samuel and Alma Glover.Â  
[4] Glover initially brought this action against Albert alleging fraud in the procurement of a tax deed and to establish a prescriptive easement.Â  Albert moved to dismiss, asserting Glover (1) lacked standing to bring the action, (2) failed to plead fraud with sufficient particularity, (3) failed to set forth facts sufficient to constitute causes of action, and (4) failed to name all necessary parties.Â  Glover filed an amended complaint, adding the Tax Collector as a necessary party and pleading the elements of fraud, thus remedying two of the alleged deficiencies.Â  Glover also added a claim for a constructive trust.Â  
[5] Â The circuit court noted Glover alleged that neither she nor Albert were â€œheirsâ€ of Daisey Glover.Â  Although Glover did allege at one point that she and her brother were not heirs of Daisey Glover, this does not vitiate her allegation that she has some kind of ownership interest in the property along with her brother as the two allegations are not necessarily mutually exclusive.
[6] Â The circuit court similarly observed in the case before us that Glover â€œdoes not appear to actually allege the Delinquent Tax Collector did anything improper in the process.â€Â  We note Glover added the Tax Collector as a party only after Albert moved to dismiss the complaint based partly on the alleged failure to join all indispensable parties.Â  Glover alleges in her amended complaint that the Tax Collector was given false information from Albert that caused the Tax Collector to issue a tax deed.Â  Glover affirmatively stated, however, the Tax Collector did not do anything improper in following the statutes governing tax sales and stated this would not prevent the deed from being voidable due to fraud in its procurement.Â Â Â  
[7]Â  We remand for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.Â  In her brief, Glover requested that, in the event we upheld the circuit courtâ€™s order, we remand this case with instructions to the circuit court to grant her leave to amend her complaint â€œto properly assert the status of her father, Samuel Glover, as an heir of Thomas Glover; and, if necessary, to also amend so as to assert her own interests as a potential subsequent heir in order to proceed in a manner seeking to fully clear title to the property.â€Â  Since we are reversing the dismissal of the complaint and remanding for further proceedings, Glover should address any motions she deems appropriate to the circuit court, which may hear them in its own discretion.Â  An amendment of the pleadings might be desirable to clarify any perceived contradictory portions therein.
