PER CURIAM: Thomas Thorne appeals the family courtâ€™s order terminating his parental rights from T.J. (â€œChildâ€).Â  Thorne argues the family court erred in finding (1) Thorne willfully failed to visit Child, (2) Thorne willfully failed to support Child, (3) Thorne abandoned Child, (4) Child was in foster care for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months, and (5) termination of parental rights (â€œTPRâ€) was in the best interest of Child.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
In a TPR case, the best interest of the child is the paramount consideration.Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Before the family court grants TPR, the alleged grounds for the termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  On appeal, this court may review the record and make its own determination whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Despite this broad scope of review, however, we should not necessarily disregard the findings of the family court, because the family court is in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
The family court may order TPR if â€œ[t]he child has lived outside the home of either parent for a period of six months, and during that time the parent has willfully failed to support the child.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2006).Â  Willful conduct is conduct that â€œevinces a settled purpose to forego parental duties . . . because it manifests a conscious indifference to the rights of the child to receive support and consortium from the parent.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 53, 413 S.E.2d 835, 838 (1992).Â  From January 2003, when the South Carolina Department of Social Services (â€œDSSâ€) took Child into emergency custody, until September 2003, when Thorne was incarcerated, Thorne did not support Child.Â  Thorneâ€™s only defense is that he was not required to support Child because there was not a child support order in place requiring him to do so.Â  As the father of Child, Thorne was obligated to support Child regardless of the existence or nonexistence of a court order mandating he support Child.Â  Stinecipher v. Ballington, 366 S.C. 92, 620 S.E.2d 93 (Ct. App. 2005) (holding father was not relieved of his duty to support his child merely because childâ€™s custodial parents never requested support).Â  The family court did not err in finding Thorne willfully failed to support Child for six months. 
The family court also did not err in finding TPR was in the best interest of Child.Â  Both a DSS caseworker and Childâ€™s Guardian ad Litem testified that Child was doing well with Childâ€™s foster family.Â  Child has been with this foster family for over four years, and they wish to adopt Child.Â  Conversely, Child has had almost no interaction with Thorne, both before and after Thorneâ€™s imprisonment.Â  The family court correctly found TPR was in the best interest of Child.Â  
Accordingly, the family court did not err in finding Thorne willfully failed to support Child for six months and that TPR was in the best interest of Child.[2]Â  The family courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Because we find the family court did not err in finding Thorne willfully failed to support Child for six months, we decline to address Thorneâ€™s remaining assignments of error.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (proscribing that the family court may grant TPR â€œupon a finding of one or moreâ€ of the statutory grounds outlined in section 20-7-1572, and a finding that TPR is in the best interest of the child); Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. King, 369 S.C. 96, 101, 631 S.E.2d 239, 241 (2006) (â€œBecause one statutory ground for TPR has been met, the only issue remaining for us to consider is whether termination is in the best interest of the child.â€).

PER CURIAM:Â  Rebecca Ramsey appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting a declaratory judgment for American National Property and Casualty Insurance Company (â€œAmerican Nationalâ€).Â  The circuit court held that although an exclusion in American Nationalâ€™s policy was void, as it conflicted with the South Carolina Motor Vehicle Financial Responsibility Act (â€œActâ€), the exclusion was void only to the minimum liability coverage mandated by the act.Â  We affirm.[1]
At the time of the accident, South Carolina law required minimum liability coverage of $15,000.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-140 (2002).Â  South Carolina law also allowed an insurer to exclude coverage in excess of the minimum liability coverage.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-9-20(5)(d) (2002) (proscribing that if an insurer chooses to provide excess liability coverage, the excess coverage â€œshall not be subject to the provisions of [the Act].â€).Â  Accordingly, American National was entitled to exclude coverage in excess of the statutory minimum liability coverage of $15,000.Â  
In this case, the policy American National issued to Ramsey excluded liability coverage for family members living with the insured.Â  This exclusion was triggered because at the time of the accident the decedent shared a home with the insured, the decedentâ€™s brother.Â  This exclusion was void, however, because it violated section 38-77-30 of the South Carolina Code (2002), which provides that an insured includes a resident relative.Â  
The question before the circuit court was whether the exclusion was void only to the extent it excludes minimum liability coverage provided by statute, or void as to the entire policy.Â  American National argued the exclusion was void only to the extent of the statutory minimum liability coverage, and, therefore, American National owed Ramsey $15,000, which American National already paid.Â  Ramsey argued the exclusion was void to the full policy limits, and, therefore, American National owed Ramsey $235,000 (the $250,000 Policy limit minus the $15,000 statutory minimum limit American National already paid Ramsey).Â  The circuit court ruled the exclusion was void only to the extent of the statutory minimum liability coverage.Â  
We concur with the circuit court.Â  In Hansen v. USAA, 350 S.C. 62, 565 S.E.2d 114 (Ct. App. 2002), we held that excess coverage beyond the statutory minimum liability coverage is governed by the terms of the contract.Â  Hansen controls this case.[2]Â  Thus, American National could (and did) exclude excess coverage beyond the statutory minimum liability coverage of $15,000.Â  Because American National has already paid Ramsey the statutory minimum liability of $15,000, it has satisfied its obligation to Ramsey under the policy.Â  
The circuit courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR. 
[2]Â  Ramsey argues Hansen is distinguishable because in Hansen the policy expressly provided that the insurer would cover the statutory minimum liability coverage, while in this case the policy does not.Â  Hansen is not distinguishable for this reason because the policy at issue in this case provides that American National will cover the statutory minimum liability coverage:

  CONFORMITY WITH STATE FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY LAWS
  When we certify this policy as proof under a state financial responsibility law, it will comply with that law to the extent of the coverage and limits of liability required by that law. 

(emphasis in original).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
        v.
        Tina Jean N., Clifford S., and John Doe,Â  of whom Tina Jean N. is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Â Alvin D. Johnson, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-221
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed May 14, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Scott David Robinson, of Pickens, for Appellant.
        Scarlet Moore, of Greenville, for Respondent.
        Michael Anthony Andrews, of Easley, and Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Tina Jean N. (Mother) appeals from the family courtâ€™s order terminating her parental rights to her minor child based on a finding that the child was harmed and it is not reasonably likely that the home can be made safe within twelve months.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Mother and Clifford S. (Father) were never married; however, their relationship produced a child.Â  The child, born in December 2001, has always remained in the custody of Mother.Â  Father exercised very limited visitation with the child.Â  In October 2004, he sought to increase his visitation with the child.Â  
On February 7, 2005, Father picked the child up for the childâ€™s first overnight visit with Father.Â  While in Fatherâ€™s custody, the child was taken to a farm where Father frequently worked.Â  The child was seen getting up off the ground with a bull calf running away. Â It was assumed the calf had kicked the child.Â  Father did not take the child to a doctor for any medical care.Â  On February 8, he returned the child to Mother.Â Â  
Mother examined the child after learning about the possible incident with the calf and found a quarter size bruise.Â  The child was sore, but behaved normally.Â  The following day, Mother took the child to a previously scheduled ENT visit for follow-up regarding an ear infection.Â  Dr. Brown noticed numerous bruises to the childâ€™s face and lower arms.Â  Mother explained the bruises were caused when the child was trampled by the calf.Â  Dr. Brown noted his suspicion of abuse, but indicated he did not believe it was the situation.Â  Â 
On February 10, 2005, Father again picked the child up for an overnight visit.Â  He kept the child until February 12, when he returned the child to Mother.Â  Father believed the time to be 12 to 12:30 p.m. when he returned the child.Â  Mother believed it was between 2 and 2:30 that afternoon.Â  When the child was returned, Mother found the child had been burned on its arm and back.Â  Father explained the burn occurred when the child fell into a bath of exceedingly hot water.Â  
At 3:39 Mother called her family doctor, Dr. Ardis. Â During the conversation, she relayed the fact the child had bruising that was getting worse and that the child had been burned.Â  Dr. Ardis instructed her to take the child to the emergency room at Palmetto Health Baptist in Easley.Â  The child arrived at the hospital at approximately 4:00 p.m. with life threatening injuries.Â  
 The child had five broken ribs; a â€œbucket handleâ€ fracture of her forearm; internal bleeding around her liver and adrenal gland; second degree burns to her arm; burns to the left side of her abdomen; scabs on her face and ear; areas behind her ear where hair had been pulled out; â€œslash burnsâ€ to her face; a massive bruise to her buttocks; a one-inch tear to her perineum; and numerous other bruises, scars, and scabs throughout her body.Â  The child required a blood transfusion due to the massive injuries she sustained.Â  Also found was a loop scar, which is emblematic of abuse by whipping with a belt or cord.Â  Due to the extreme injuries, the child was air lifted to Greenville Memorial Hospitalâ€™s Pediatric Intensive Care Unit (PICU).Â  
The child was taken into protective custody and a probable cause hearing was held on February 14.Â  The child remained in the hospital for thirteen days, until February 25, when the child was placed with a foster care home.Â  The Department of Social Services (DSS) brought this action for termination of parental rights (TPR) against Mother and Father on the ground that the child has been harmed as defined in section 20-7-490, and because of the severity or repetition of the abuse or neglect, it is not reasonably likely that the home can be made safe within twelve months.Â  Hearings were held over multiple days which resulted in extensive testimony regarding the injuries sustained by the child.
Dr. Michael Avant, a pediatric critical care physician that treated the child at Greenville Memorial Hospital, testified to the childâ€™s terrible injuries.Â  He explained that several of the injuries were older than a week, and others were inflicted within forty-eight hours of the child arriving at the hospital.Â  He also testified the child was in pain when she arrived and needed â€œsignificant pain management.â€ Â Â 
Dr. Avant stated he learned the reasons given by the parents for the injuries were the child fell into a hot bath causing the burns and was kicked by a calf causing the bruising.Â  Dr. Avant explained the injuries suffered by the child were not consistent with falling in a tub or being kicked by a calf.Â  He testified the injuries were â€œnonaccidental.â€Â  
Dr. Avant averred the child would have been in obvious need of immediate medical attention from the number and extent of injuries.Â  Regarding Motherâ€™s delay in seeking medical care after the child was allegedly returned home at 2:00 in the same condition he witnessed at the hospital, Dr. Avant opined:Â  â€œThis child obviously needed medical attention immediately.Â  You know, to me these were impressive injuries that should have resulted in alarm.Â  Any delay I would have to question.â€Â  
In discussing some of the specific injuries, Dr. Avant stated he believed the tear to the childâ€™s perineum was caused by something being forced into the child or either a very severe straddle injury, neither of which would be consistent with a kick by a calf. Â He testified some of the scars on the childâ€™s legs looked like cigarette burns that were more than a couple days old.Â  Finally, he testified the burns on the childâ€™s arm and abdomen clearly were not caused by a fall into a tub of water, but instead looked like â€œit [was] poured down her.â€ 
Dr. Nancy Henderson, the medical director of the trauma center at Greenville Hospital System, testified she reviewed the childâ€™s medical records and found the previous fifty-one visits to physicians to be â€œconcerning.â€Â  She was surprised Mother would not have taken the child to see a doctor after the alleged incident with the calf given Motherâ€™s history of reporting a wide variety of ailments.Â  Â 
Dr. Henderson was bothered by the amount and frequency of doctorâ€™s visits as well as whether a true need existed for some of the childâ€™s medications.Â  She was also â€œvery concerned that maybe some of the symptoms that [were] being shared to the physicians were not there.â€Â  Dr. Henderson testified that because the child was later doing so well without any medication, there was concern that either the ailments did not exist or were being exaggerated.Â  Finally, she opined Munchausen by Proxy was a real possibility as an explanation for the complete resolution of the childâ€™s medical problems once the child was removed from Motherâ€™s care. 
Dr. Lori Carnsew evaluated the child after she was removed from the parents and again shortly before the hearing on May 16, 2005.Â  She stated the child was healing and was no longer taking the medications she was prescribed while in Motherâ€™s care.Â  Additionally, she stated: â€œThere are no signs currently of any illnesses.â€Â  
Next Dr. Carnsew testified regarding a couple of the childâ€™s injuries.Â  She testified there were areas behind the childâ€™s ears where hair was missing and either slowly growing back or still missing.Â Â  She stated the only explanation for the missing hair was that it was pulled out.Â  Finally, she testified the child had a â€œlooped scarâ€ on her back.Â  She testified a looped scar is â€œpretty much a hallmark of child abuseâ€ and â€œitâ€™s made with an electrical cord or some kind of cord being folded in half and used as a whip.â€Â  
Ann Moser, a nurse in the PICU, testified the child was in excruciating pain and had to receive morphine due to her injuries.Â  Moser recounted statements made by the child which were admitted pursuant to section 19-1-180 of the South Carolina Code.Â  â€œSeveral asked, you know, what happened or if she had a boo-boo or whatever.Â  And at one point she had said, â€˜My momma did it.Â  Mommy did it.â€™â€Â  
Moser opined that the injuries suffered by the child were not at all consistent with being kicked or trampled by a calf or resulted from a fall.Â  Â Moser testified the injuries were, in her experience, the result of abuse.Â  In addressing Motherâ€™s delay in seeking medical care from 2:30 until 3:39, Moser stated unequivocally:Â  â€œAnything longer than one minute or two minutes to look at her, I believe would have been neglect.â€Â  
 The child also made statements to three additional nurses while in Greenville Memorial Hospitalâ€™s PICU.Â  Caroline Cullinane testified the child told her â€œMommy did itâ€ when she was asked about her hurt arm.Â  Jenny Rohr testified the child told her that â€œmy mommyâ€ caused the â€œboo-booâ€ on her belly and nose.Â  When asked about her arm, Rohr stated the child told her that her mommy and daddy did it.Â  Brenda Dawley, the third nurse, explained:Â  â€œI said, how did you get that owie on your nose? . . . And she answered me, â€˜Mommy.â€™â€Â  Dawley then continued:Â  â€œAnd I said, did your â€“ â€˜Your mommy did that?â€™ And she said, â€˜Yes.â€™Â  I said, â€˜Well, why would she do that?â€™ And she said, â€˜Because she hates me.â€™â€
 Mother also presented several witnesses.Â  Motherâ€™s father testified that Mother and the child have a loving relationship.Â  He further testified that the child called most women mama if the child heard someone else call them by that name.Â  Several witnesses testified the child was a happy, cheerful girl that was well cared for by Mother and had a great relationship with Mother. Â 
Denise Sudlek, a friend of Mother and formerly a registered nurse, testified the bruises and other injuries were not visible when she saw the child the week before February 12.Â  She also stated she was the person who recommended Mother keep a journal of bruises and scrapes the child received because then Mother would be able to show the doctor how things happened and the doctor could help determine if something was wrong.Â  However, on cross-examination, she admitted having concerns about the number of doctor visits to which the Mother took the child.Â  Additionally, Sudlek was worried about the behavior of the child in which the child would repeatedly get up from the table to tell her mother that she loved her.Â  Sudlek explained, based on her experience, the behavior occurred because the child was â€œeither very insecure because of things that were going on around them or that they were being abused.â€Â  Finally, in discussing the testimony that the child indicated â€œMommyâ€ was the one that hurt her, Sudlek offered that children as young as the child â€œdonâ€™t know how to lie.â€Â  
Dr. Karen Ardis, a family practice physician in the office in which the child was routinely seen, testified she received the call from Mother at 3:39 p.m. that the child had been hurt.Â  Dr. Ardis described the call:

  She said she was calling about [the child] that she had been kicked by a calf several days ago and had bruising.Â  She then said that the bruising she thought was getting worse.Â  And she said, yes, it is worse.Â  Itâ€™s open and draining now.Â  Then she said, but Iâ€™m not calling about the bruising, [the child] had fallen into a tub of hot water exceedingly hot water and burned herself.Â  She said and some of them look like they are second degree burns and Iâ€™m not sure what I should do.Â  

Dr. Ardis advised Mother to take the child to the hospital.Â  She testified if Mother waited more than five minutes after seeing this child to seek medical assistance then it would be medical neglect.Â  
Mother reiterated the claim that the child was kicked by a calf around February 7 while in the custody of Father.Â  She also stated Father told her the child fell into a bath of exceedingly hot water, which caused the burns.Â  She then asserted the child was not crying, though she was hurting, when Father brought her home on February 12.Â  Mother examined the child, became frantic, and gathered items to take with the child to the hospital.Â  Mother also stated the child played with her toy lawn mower and climbed onto the sofa to rest.Â  Mother stated it was immediately after viewing the child and gathering the childâ€™s blanket and doll that they headed out to the doctor. Â She stated it was after she had left the home that she called Dr. Ardis.Â  
Fatherâ€™s parents testified the child ate breakfast on February 12 before she returned home to Mother.Â  However, the childâ€™s paternal grandfather testified he did not run a bath the night the child allegedly fell into a bath of hot water.Â  He also stated he did not know the child had been burned until later.Â  
The Guardian ad Litem testified the child has been healing and doing well since being removed from Motherâ€™s custody.Â  She testified the child is no longer on the many medicines prescribed while in Motherâ€™s custody, nor is she suffering from any of the ailments such as chronic vomiting, asthma, or lactose intolerance. 
 The guardian also testified regarding some of the childâ€™s behaviors since she was placed into protective custody.Â  She stated the child would hit her doll and when asked why she would say because the â€œbaby peed in its pants.â€Â  In addition, the guardian testified the child has never asked for her mother or shown signs of being homesick in the months she has been out of Motherâ€™s custody.Â  Finally, the guardian testified unequivocally that the termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights was in the best interest of the child. 
The court issued a very detailed thirty-one page order in which the court recounted the testimony of the experts and other witnesses.Â  The court found there was clear and convincing evidence Mother harmed the child as defined in section 20-7-490 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  In addition, the court found clear and convincing evidence that because of the severity and repetition of the abuse it was unlikely the home could be made safe. The family court determined it was in the childâ€™s best interest that Motherâ€™s parental rights be terminated.Â  The court then ordered the parental rights of Mother be terminated and the child be placed in the custody of DSS.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Section 20-7-1578 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) mandates that the TPR statutes â€œmust be liberally construed in order to ensure prompt judicial procedures for freeing minor children from the custody and control of their parents by terminating the parent-child relationship.â€Â  See also Joiner v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 536 S.E.2d 372 (2000) (overruling prior cases calling for strict construction of the TPR statutes).Â  In a termination of parental rights case, the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Smith, 343 S.C. 129, 133, 538 S.E.2d 285, 287 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œThe interests of the child shall prevail if the childâ€™s interest and the parental rights conflict.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578.Â  Grounds for termination of parental rights must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 608-09, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003) (citing Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 102 S. Ct. 1388, 71 L. Ed. 2d 599 (1982)).
â€œUpon review, the appellate court may make its own finding from the record as to whether clear and convincing evidence supports the termination.â€Â  Headden, 354 S.C. at 609, 582 S.E.2d at 423.Â  The reviewing court, however, is not required â€œto ignore the fact that the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 367 (1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Ground for Termination
Mother contends the family court erred in finding her parental rights could be terminated pursuant to section 20-7-1572(1) of the South Carolina Code (2005).Â  She maintains DSS failed to prove by clear and convincing evidence the abuse was at the hands of Mother and instead, the abuse only occurred during a single incident while the child was in the care and custody of Father.Â  Finally, Mother asserts there had been no repetitive abuse of any prior instances of abuse indicating Motherâ€™s home could not be made safe once Father was not involved.Â  We disagree.
Section 20-7-1572(1) states:

  The family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one or more of the following grounds and a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child:
  (1) The child . . . has been harmed as defined in Section 20-7-490, and because of the severity or repetition of the abuse or neglect, it is not reasonably likely that the home can be made safe within twelve months.Â  In determining the likelihood that the home can be made safe, the parentâ€™s previous abuse or neglect of the child or another child in the home may be considered . . . .

â€œChild abuse or neglectâ€ or â€œharmâ€ is defined as occurring:

  when the parent, guardian, or other person responsible for the childâ€™s welfare:
  (a) inflicts or allows to be inflicted upon the child physical or mental injury or engages in acts or omissions which present a substantial risk of physical or mental injury to the child, including injuries sustained as a result of excessive corporal punishment . . . .Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-490(2) (2005).
Mother points to three cases to argue that DSS failed to prove the ground for termination by clear and convincing evidence.Â  First, Mother cites Greenville County Department of Social Services v. Bowes, 313 S.C. 188, 437 S.E.2d 107 (1993).Â  In Bowes, the court found DSS failed to prove the same ground alleged in the instant case because it failed to prove the child was abused by clear and convincing evidence.Â  The court found DSS never offered any evidence â€œthe bruising in February 1991 was the result of abuse but submitted only the removal order which found physical abuse based on this incident.â€Â  Id. at 193, 437 S.E.2d at 110.Â  However, this case is easily distinguished given the abundant evidence presented over multiple days regarding the severe abuse suffered by the child.Â  Â Â Â 
Next, Mother points this court to South Carolina Department of Social Services v. Brown, 317 S.C. 332, 454 S.E.2d 335 (Ct. App. 1995), and Shake v. Darlington County Department of Social Services, 306 S.C. 216, 410 S.E.2d 923 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  In Brown, a child died while in the custody of the father and the mother was at work. Â All evidence indicated the mother could not have played a role in the abuse that lead to the childâ€™s death.Â  Brown, 317 S.C. at 338, 454 S.E.2d at 338.Â  Additionally, no evidence was ever presented showing the mother abused the deceased child or other children in the home or neglected any child after it was previously abused by the father.Â  Id.Â  Finally, this court found the home could be made safe for the remaining children through the removal of the father, the only one shown to have abused the deceased child.Â  Id. at 339, 454 S.E.2d at 338-39.
In Shake, this court affirmed the family courtâ€™s refusal to terminate the motherâ€™s parental rights when then only evidence in the record indicated the child was abused in a solitary incident involving excessive corporal punishment by the motherâ€™s boyfriend when the mother was not at home.Â  Shake, 306 S.C. at 220, 410 S.E.2d at 925.Â  As will be discussed below, the case at hand does not involve a single isolated incident or only one parent as abuser with the other parent being an innocent party based on the record.
Based on the horrific facts discussed above, the only conclusion that can be reached is that the child suffered extreme abuse and harm.Â  The testimony clearly indicates much of the harm originated at times when Mother was in full custody of the child.Â  First and foremost, the child identified â€œmommyâ€ as the person that caused several of her injuries.Â  Four different witnesses testified the child told them that various injuries, from scabs on her face to arm injuries, were caused by Mother.Â  All witnesses testified the child was not capable of lying.Â  The testimony was admitted by the court pursuant to section 19-1-180 of the South Carolina Code (2006), and the admissibility of the testimony has not been challenged on appeal.
While some of the harm obviously occurred at the hands of Father, Mother was also abusive.Â  The loop scar was clearly a sign of prior abuse which did not originate while the child was in Fatherâ€™s custody.Â  Other bruises, scabs, and scars were described by medical experts as older than two or three days, meaning that they likely occurred while in the custody of Mother. Moreover, the testimony by numerous individuals graphically detailed the childâ€™s injuries on February 12 and several experts testified it would have been impossible for the child to travel from Greenville to Easley in that condition.Â  Therefore, the above cases can be distinguished because there is clear and convincing evidence Mother abused the child.
In addition to the injuries detectible on February 12, there was evidence the abuse and neglect was ongoing for years.Â  Testimony by numerous medical personnel indicated it was likely Mother was manufacturing medical problems in order to seek treatment for the child.Â  In three years, the child was seen over fifty-one times by doctors.Â  The complaints ranged from acid reflux to asthma to chronic diarrhea and vomiting.Â  The child was placed on numerous medications to alleviate the symptoms, usually based in part on the histories given by Mother.Â  However, since being removed from Motherâ€™s custody, the symptoms have all resolved and the child has not required any of the prior medications.
Finally, even if many of the injuries resulted from events out of Motherâ€™s control, numerous witnesses testified it was medical neglect to delay the child receiving medical treatment.Â  If the story told by the parents is to be believed, many of these injuries occurred on February 7 at the latest.Â  To wait until February 12 to seek medical attention is clearly neglect.Â  Even if the injuries resulted from events prior to the child being returned to Motherâ€™s custody at 2:30 in the afternoon on February 12, to wait over an hour until 3:39 to seek any medical advice was inexcusable and in the testimony of many witnesses, including several defense witnesses, it was blatant medical neglect.Â  
The family courtâ€™s thirty-one page order fully detailed the testimony and the evidence relied on in terminating Motherâ€™s parental rights.Â  Based on the voluminous record before us, we find there was abounding evidence supporting a finding by the family court that the child â€œhas been harmed as defined in Section 20-7-490, and because of the severity or repetition of the abuse or neglect, it is not reasonably likely that the home can be made safe within twelve months.â€Â  Â Â Â Â 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Best Interest of the Child
Mother argues the best interest of the child are not served through TPR, but are served by being reunited with Mother.Â  We disagree.
In a termination of parental rights case, the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Smith, 343 S.C. 129, 133, 538 S.E.2d 285, 287 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  If the parentâ€™s and childâ€™s interests conflict, the childâ€™s interest prevails.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578.
The brutality of the abuse and the long term effects of the abuse are sufficient reasons to justify terminating Motherâ€™s parental rights.Â  Moreover, the child is thriving in her current situation.Â  After being removed from Motherâ€™s custody, the child has become free from numerous medications, which may not have been necessary.Â  In addition, the testimony indicates the child is healing, both emotionally and physically, from her injuries. Further, the guardian and others testified that the termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights is in the best interest of the child. Â Therefore, it is clear from our reading of this record that the best interest of this child is served by terminating Motherâ€™s parental rights to the child.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based upon our own view of this record, we find clear and convincing evidence supports the family courtâ€™s determination that Mother abused the child, the home could not be made safe, and termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights was in the best interest of the child.Â  Accordingly, the order of the family court is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Rayford Butler, Respondent,
        v.
        South Carolina Department of Education, Employer, State Accident Fund, Carrier, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-226
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“Filed May 14, 2007

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Margaret M. Urbanic, of Charleston and Cynthia Polk, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Nowell S. Lesser, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: This is a workersâ€™ compensation case.Â  Rayford Butler (â€œClaimantâ€) was injured on July 5, 2000 when he lifted a brake drum while working for the South Carolina Department of Education (â€œthe Departmentâ€).Â  The single commissioner found 35% permanent partial disability to Claimantâ€™s spine.Â  An appellate panel of the full commission affirmed and adopted the single commissionerâ€™s order.Â  The circuit court affirmed the commission to the extent it found Claimant suffered a 35% permanent partial disability to his neck.Â  The circuit court reversed the commissionâ€™s order to the extent no other compensable injury was found and remanded the case for a determination of the extent of additional permanent partial disability due to permanent injuries to Claimantâ€™s lower back.Â  The Department appeals and we reverse.[1]
I.
After Claimantâ€™s accident, he was treated by Southeastern Spine Institute for the following symptoms: low back pain radiating down his left leg to the foot, left neck pain that radiates in the left thumb and index finger, and numbness and pain in his left hand and forearm.Â  Claimant was initially treated by Dr. Jeffrey Wingate who prescribed physical therapy, epidural injections, and anti-inflammatory and muscle relaxing drugs.Â  Claimant also had a CT myelogram which revealed a L3-4 foraminal bulge as a result of an annular tear which displaces the L4 nerve root.Â  When Claimantâ€™s symptoms persisted, Dr. Wingate referred Claimant to Dr. Leonard Forrest.Â  Dr. Forrest scheduled Claimant for a nerve conduction study.Â  The nerve conduction study, performed by Dr. Robert Richardson on April 6, 2001, showed no evidence of cervical or lumbar radiculopathy.Â  
A functional capacity evaluation conducted on October 4, 2001, revealed that â€œthe patient manifested some self-limiting behaviorâ€ and â€œit might be reasonable to allow him to work at a Light level for three hours per day, ramping up to an 8-hour per day as tolerated.â€Â  Further, it noted â€œif allowed to work at the Sedentary level, it may be likely that he will be able to tolerate the 8-hour day.â€Â  
Claimant was seen by George Cogar, Ph.D., for a psychological evaluation on November 20, 2001.Â  Cogar opined that if Claimantâ€™s sleep were improved that his depression and response to pain would improve.Â  He recommended a drug to help Claimant sleep.Â  Cogar saw Claimant several more times and, on April 10, 2002, noted, â€œI would indicate he is at maximum psychological improvement and I will continue to see him prn.â€Â  
On May 13, 2002, Claimant was seen by Dr. Jeffrey Faaberg of the Crowfield Pain Center.Â  Dr. Faaberg found Claimant to be at MMI.Â  Specifically, regarding Claimantâ€™s cervical spine, thoracic spine, and lumbar spine, he opined, â€œTotal whole person impairment . . . is therefore 20%.â€Â  Dr. Faaberg also added â€œan additional 5% whole person impairment secondary to significant major depressive findings mentioned by George Cogar Ph.D. in his psychological evaluation.â€
On March 1, 2002, Dr. Forrest reported that Claimant was at MMI.Â  Dr. Forrest ascribed Claimant a â€œ5% permanent impairment rating for his neck and a 5% permanent impairment rating for the low back.Â  The sum total is therefore a 10% permanent impairment rating for [Claimant].â€Â  Dr. Forrest also found that Claimant â€œcould work a sedentary level beginning at any time and do that on a full time basis.â€Â  On January 20, 2003, Dr. Forrest again stated, â€œ[Claimant] remains at maximum medical improvement as previously defined.â€Â  On August 25, 2003, Dr. Forrest found, â€œthere is no definite weakness in the extremities.â€Â  
On October 31, 2003, after Claimant complained of increased pain in his neck, upper back, and arms, Dr. Forrest suggested Claimant have a surgical evaluation.Â  In this regard, Dr. Donald Johnson saw Claimant on December 3, 2003 and recommended surgery.Â  On February 24, 2004, Claimant underwent a fusion at C6-7.Â  On June 3, 2004, Dr. Johnson stated, â€œI do think in regards to his cervical spine [Claimant] has reached maximum medical improvement . . . he has sustained a 25% impairment to the whole person.â€Â  The June 3, 2004 report further noted, â€œIf [a CAT scan of Claimantâ€™s lumbar spine] is normal I would place him at maximum medical improvement in regards to his lumbar spine also.â€Â  An August 18, 2004 addendum to the June 3, 2004 report by Dr. Johnson opines that a CT myelogram was conducted on June 14, 2004 and showed â€œsome degenerative changes at 4-5 with minimal stenosis.â€Â  Dr. Johnson then opined, â€œI would continue to place him at maximum medical improvement and feel my note of June 3, 2004 is appropriate.â€Â  
On November 9, 2004, Claimant testified before the single commissioner that he continues to suffer from numbness in his left arm and hand; pain in his hips, legs, shoulders, neck and low back; headaches; and depression.Â  
The single commission ordered and an appellate panel of the commission affirmed that the Department pay Claimant â€œpermanent partial disability benefits equal to 35% to the spine at a compensation rate of $267.18.â€Â  The commission further found that â€œClaimantâ€™s injury is confined to his spine and no other body parts are compensable.â€Â  
The circuit court affirmed the commissionâ€™s order to the extent it found Claimant â€œsustained a 35% permanent partial disability to his neck.â€Â  The circuit court reversed, however, â€œto the extent that it found no other compensable injury[.]â€Â  The circuit court found the commissionâ€™s ruling of no other compensable injuries was not supported by the substantial evidence, and specifically noted the undisputed evidence that Claimant sustained permanent injuries to his low back.Â  Further, the circuit court determined the commission erred by: (1) considering only the medical evidence relating to Claimantâ€™s neck injuries; (2) finding that Claimantâ€™s injuries were confined to his spine; and (3) disregarding the significant permanent restrictions imposed by Dr. Forrest.Â  
II.
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  â€œIn workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder.â€Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  This court reviews facts based on the substantial evidence standard.Â  Thompson v. S.C. Steel Erectors, 369 S.C. 606, 612, 632 S.E.2d 874, 877 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Under the substantial evidence standard, the appellate court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2006).Â  The appellate court may reverse or modify the Commissionâ€™s decision only if the Claimantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Id.Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side, but such evidence, when the whole record is considered, as would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the Full Commission reached.â€Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.
  III.
The Department argues the circuit court incorrectly found that (1) the commissionâ€™s award only applied to Claimantâ€™s cervical spine and (2) that the commission only considered the medical evidence relating to Claimantâ€™s neck injuries.Â  We agree.
In its order, the commission specifically stated, â€œthe Claimant suffered an admitted injury to his neck and back . . . .â€Â  The commission also noted Claimantâ€™s testimony of â€œshooting pain in his neck and back.â€Â  Moreover, the commission specifically awarded Claimant â€œpermanent partial disability benefits equal to 35% to the spine . . . .â€Â  (Emphasis added.)Â  The commission did not differentiate between Claimantâ€™s neck and lower back.Â  The award for Claimantâ€™s spine injury contemplates both his neck and lower backâ€”contrary to the circuit courtâ€™s finding. 
The commission referred to both Dr. Johnsonâ€™s June 3, 2004 and August 18, 2004 reports, which were written after Claimantâ€™s surgery.Â  As noted by the commission, on June 3 Dr. Johnson found Claimant to be at maximum medical improvement with a 25% whole person impairment rating.Â  The commission also stated that on August 18, Dr. Johnson found some degenerative changes but continued to opine Claimant was at MMI.Â  The August 18 report, which the commission clearly referred to in its order, states Claimant reached MMI and refers back to Dr. Johnsonâ€™s June 3 report.Â  These reports, when read together, provide substantial evidence supporting the commissionâ€™s finding.
IV.
The circuit court found the commission erred by failing to make any reference to the permanent work restrictions recommended for Claimant by Dr. Forrest in a questionnaire for Claimantâ€™s Social Security hearing.Â  The Department argues the circuit court erred in making this finding.Â  We agree.Â  
The questionnaire and restrictions referred to by the circuit court were made by Dr. Forrest on December 18, 2003.Â  Dr. Johnsonâ€™s finding of MMI was made several months later on June 3, 2004 and after Claimantâ€™s surgery on February 24, 2004.Â  Therefore, the evidence supports the commissionâ€™s findings.Â  The circuit court reweighed the evidence to come to a different findingâ€”an action not permitted by the standard of review.Â  
V.
The circuit court found the commission erred in finding Claimantâ€™s injuries were confined to his spine and that no other injuries were compensable.Â  The Department argues the circuit court made findings outside the scope of review.Â  We agree.
The single commissionerâ€™s order shows that the commission reviewed the medical evidence and found that Claimantâ€™s only compensable injury was to his spine.Â  The order states that â€œ[t]he medical evidence supports a C5 injury with some radicular symptoms in the arm which comes from the neck injury.Â  Medical evidence does not demonstrate other injuries to the arms or legs.â€Â  
Although Claimant consistently reported pain and numbness in his upper and lower extremities, no doctor found these areas to be injured.Â  In fact, on August 25, 2003, Dr. Forrest found â€œno definite weakness in the [Claimantâ€™s] extremities.â€Â  As we read the medical evidence, the pain and numbness in Claimantâ€™s extremities is a symptom of his spinal injury.Â  In any event, the record substantially supports the commissionâ€™s finding.Â  The circuit court erred in conducting its own review of the evidence and concluding otherwise.Â  

  VI.
For the reasons stated above, we reverse the circuit court.
REVERSED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ericka L. Jones, Appellant,
				v.
				South Carolina Department of Social Services, Employer, and State Accident Fund, Carrier, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-243
Heard April 10, 2007 â€“ Filed May 22, 2007
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Kevin B. Smith, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Ajerenal Danley, Matthew C. Robertson and Cynthia Burns Polk, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â This is a workersâ€™ compensation case.Â  The claimant, Ericka L. Jones, alleged she suffered a mental-mental injury arising out of and in the course of her employment as a caseworker for the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS).Â  The single commissioner denied the claim, finding the greater weight of the evidence did not support a finding that Jonesâ€™s emotional condition arose out of and in the course of her employment.Â  The appellate panel and circuit court affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s order.Â  Jones appeals to this court. Â We reverse and remand.
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Jones was hired by DSS on July 31, 2000, as a Human Service Specialist II, commonly referred to as a caseworker.Â  Before working at DSS, Jones suffered from a neuromuscular disorder that caused physical problems; however, there is no evidence that she experienced any prior mental health or substance abuse problems or had received any mental health treatment.
 
One of the cases in which Jones was involved concerned a teenage girl who had been placed in foster care.Â  In September 2001, Jones initiated a pickup order for the girl after she ran away from her foster home.Â  Several months later, Jones met with the police, intending to give them information to help them locate the girl.Â  Instead, she learned the police had known of the girlâ€™s whereabouts but had ignored the pick up order because they were investigating the murder of a drug dealer with whom the girl was allegedly involved.Â  Sadly, Jones also learned during the meeting that the girl had been found murdered on the railroad tracks in Lincolnville.
Jones maintains her mental problems began after she learned of the girlâ€™s murder.Â  She initially attempted to deal with her anguish by discussing it with her mother and grandmother.Â  In July 2002, she began discussing the stress of her job with her family physician.
Shortly thereafter, Jones was assigned to work on a case involving a woman whose child was in the custody of DSS.Â  In August 2002, DSS received a fax stating the woman had made death threats against Jones and Jonesâ€™s mother.Â  Jones was frightened by the threat, prompting the DSS Office of Investigations to issue instructions that Jones was not to have any further contact with the woman.Â  Jones discussed this incident with her mother, her neurologist, and her family physician.
On December 9, 2002, Jones suffered a sudden and complete mental breakdown after being required to testify in court on some of her supervisorâ€™s cases.Â  Notwithstanding the prior instructions that Jones was to avoid contact with the woman who had threatened her, the particular case involving that individual was included among the matters on which Jones was to appear.Â  Although the woman had not been served and the case was eventually continued for that reason, a DSS paralegal acknowledged that Jones was not made aware of the defect in service and that service or lack of it is usually not ascertained until the call of the corresponding case.Â  In addition, the DSS attorney was dissatisfied with the court treatment plan that was prepared by the supervisor on another case and became argumentative with Jones during her testimony.Â  This in turn, made Jones angry, defensive, and disgusted.Â  Further complicating matters, Jonesâ€™s pager went off in court alerting her to emergencies in two of her other cases.
 
As Jones was leaving the courtroom after the hearing, she began feeling weak, losing her vision, and dropping her files on the floor.Â  The following morning, her family took her to the emergency room at St. Francis Hospital.Â  On December 1, 2003, DSS terminated Jonesâ€™s employment in accordance with its attendance and leave policy.Â  Jones remains unable to work and under active psychiatric and psychological care.
On June 7, 2004, Jones applied for workersâ€™ compensation benefits, alleging she sustained a mental-mental injury arising out of and in the course of her employment with DSS.Â  The State Accident Fund denied Jones sustained a compensable injury by accident.
The matter came before the single commissioner for a hearing on August 13, 2004.Â  By order dated December 3, 2004, the single commissioner found Jones failed to prove she â€œwas operating under unusual or extraordinary conditions of employment at any time during the course of her employment with the [DSS].â€Â  The single commissioner also stated â€œthe greater weight of the evidence does not support a finding that the claimantâ€™s emotional condition arises out of and in the course of her employment with [DSS].â€
After a hearing on April 26, 2005, the appellate panel issued a summary order dated May 16, 2005, upholding and adopting the single commissionerâ€™s order.Â  The circuit court heard Jonesâ€™s petition for judicial review on June 8, 2005, and, in a form order filed May 15, 2006, denied the appeal.[1]Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Although an appellate court â€œmay not substitute [its] judgment for that of the full commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact,â€ it â€œmay reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.â€[2]Â  â€œWhile the appellate courts are required to be deferential to the full commission regarding questions of fact, this deference does not prevent the courts from overturning the full commissionâ€™s decision when it is legally incorrect.â€[3]
DISCUSSION
We agree with Jonesâ€™s argument that the commission committed an error of law in failing â€œto consider the combined or cumulative effect of the series of unusual and extraordinary untoward events that led up to [her] mental breakdown.â€Â  In our view, Jones is entitled to a finding by the commission as to whether or not the combination of factors that she cited constituted an unusual or extraordinary condition of her employment, even though each of these factors, when considered individually, would arguably be an accepted hazard in her particular job.
A claimant can recover workers compensation benefits for mental or nervous disorders resulting from â€œ â€˜emotional stimuli or stressors . . . incident to or aris[ing] from unusual or extraordinary conditions of employment.â€™ â€[4]Â  Notably, in Shealy v. Aiken County, the supreme court held various circumstances of the claimantâ€™s work as a deep-cover narcotics agent, when combined over several months, could be unusual or extraordinary conditions notwithstanding that they may all be typical of the claimantâ€™s employment.[5] 
 
In the present case, the record shows the issue of whether various stressors in Jonesâ€™s job, when considered together, caused her mental-mental injury was presented to both the single commissioner and the circuit court.Â  The single commissionerâ€™s order, however, which is the only order in the record giving more than a summary treatment to the case, failed to address this issue and instead focused on whether each of the various events leading up to Jonesâ€™s injury was in itself unusual or extraordinary or could have been a proximate cause of her breakdown.[6]Â  That is to say, despite the assertions by Jonesâ€™s attorney at the hearings before both the single commissioner and the circuit court, no findings of fact were made regarding whether the combination of the events cited in this case, all of which took place within less than a year of each other, constituted an unusual or extraordinary condition of employment proximately causing Jonesâ€™s present condition.Â  
 
Based on the foregoing, we remand this matter to the commission for a determination of (1) whether the combination of the circumstances alleged to have caused Jonesâ€™s condition constituted an unusual or extraordinary condition of her employment; and (2) if so, whether the combination of these factors proximately caused her mental-mental injury.[7]Â  In making these determinations, the commission shall confine its review to the present record.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  On May 22, 2006, Jones moved under Rule 60(b), SCRCP, for reconsideration and a â€œwritten order.â€Â  This motion was denied, and judgment in the case was entered on June 20, 2006.
[2]Â  Grant v. Grant Textiles, 372 S.C. 196, ___, 641 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2007).
[3]Â  Id.Â  at 66.Â  Although the fact that the full commission issued only a summary order was not made an issue in the present appeal, we note that in Grant, the supreme court, citing section 1-23-350 of the South Carolina Code (2005) went on to â€œreverse the full commission for its issuance of a conclusory order.â€Â  Id. at ___, 641 S.E.2d at 872.
[4]Â  Powell v. Vulcan Materials Co., 299 S.C. 325, 327, 384 S.E.2d 725, 726 (1989) (quoting Stokes v. First Natâ€™l Bank, 298 S.C. 13, 22, 377 S.E.2d 922, 927 (Ct. App. 1988)); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (1976) (providing workers compensation coverage for â€œ[s]tress . . . unaccompanied by physical injury and resulting in mental illness or injuryâ€ only if â€œit is established that the stressful employment conditions causing the mental injury were extraordinary and unusual in comparison to the normal conditions of employmentâ€).
[5]Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 459, 535 S.E.2d 438, 444 (2000). Â 
[6]Â  Moreover, the single commissionerâ€™s order, in evaluating the impact of several of the events on Jonesâ€™s emotional stability, appears to have ignored undisputed evidence that was proffered to explain why a particular occurrence was particularly stressful to her.Â  For example, although the single commissioner also found â€œthe greater weight of the credible evidence shows that the claimant was not chastised by the court on December 9, 2002,â€ he did not call into question the evidence she presented that the DSS attorney became argumentative with her while she was testifying.Â  In fact, the single commissioner acknowledged that â€œcaseworkers are sometimes chastised by the attorney in the usual course of their employment.â€Â  Similarly, the single commissioner, while appearing to find it significant that Jones was not the case manager responsible for the foster child who was later found murdered and had only limited contact with the girl, nevertheless acknowledged that it was Jones who initiated the pickup order that the police ignored.Â  Finally, although the single commissioner may have been technically correct that Jones â€œhad sufficient informationâ€ that the woman who had threatened her â€œmost probably would not be in courtâ€ when Jones was scheduled to testify, it appears undisputed that Jones could not have been completely certain that she would not have to confront the woman until the call of the case.
[7]Â  See Sigmon v. Dayco Corp., 316 S.C. 260, 262-63, 449 S.E.2d 497, 498-99 (Ct. App. 1994) (remanding the matter to the commission for findings of fact concerning the cause of the claimantâ€™s workplace injury and noting â€œ[o]nly the commission is authorized to make such findings of factâ€).

title: Horry County v. Babb
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Horry County, Respondent,
				v.
				Brenda R. Babb, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-244
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed May 22, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Brenda R. Babb, of Calabash, pro se, Appellant.
				John L. Weaver, of Conway, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  The circuit court dismissed Brenda Babbâ€™s appeal of a magistrateâ€™s court conviction for failure to register a vehicle.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On February 11, 2004, Babb was convicted in magistrateâ€™s court of failure to register a vehicle. Â On February 18, 2004, Babb filed a notice of appeal with the circuit court.Â  On February 24, 2004, Babb filed a motion for new trial with the magistrate.[2]Â  The motion included no accompanying statement of service on Horry County.Â  The notice of appeal included a certificate of service indicating it was served on the county.Â  The county denies receipt, averring it first received notice via facsimile on March 16, 2004. Â 
The county then faxed a copy of the notice of appeal to the magistrate.Â  Babb never served the notice of appeal on the magistrate.Â  In a return filed March 30, 2004, the magistrate first addresses the motion, denying it as untimely served.Â  
 
The circuit court dismissed the appeal due to Babbâ€™s failure to timely serve the notice of appeal on the magistrate. Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Babb argues the circuit court erred in dismissing her appeal for untimely service on the magistrate because she filed a motion for new trial with the magistrate, staying the time to serve her notice of appeal.Â  We disagree.
An appeal from a magistrate court conviction must be served on the magistrate within ten days of sentence.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-3-30 (1985).Â  The circuit court cannot relieve one convicted before a magistrate who has failed to timely serve the magistrate.Â  Gibbes v. Beckett, 84 S.C. 534, 536, 66 S.E. 1000, 1001 (1910).Â  Babb never served the notice of appeal on the magistrate and the county did not provide the magistrate with a copy until March 16, 2004, at the earliest.Â  
 
Babb argues, however, her motion for new trial stayed the time to serve the notice of appeal.Â  We disagree.Â  Babb relies on Rule 29(a), SCRCrimP, which provides in relevant part: â€œpost trial motions shall be made within ten (10) days after the imposition of the sentence.Â  In cases involving appeals from convictions in magistrateâ€™s or municipal court, post trial motions shall be made within ten (10) days after receipt of written notice of entry of the order or judgment disposing of the appeal.â€Â  Rule 29(a), SCRCrimP.Â  However, section 22-3-1000 of the South Carolina Code governs the issue in this case.Â  Section 22-3-1000 requires a post-trial motion for new trial, following a conviction in magistrateâ€™s court, to be made within five days of judgment.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-1000 (2007).Â  We find support for this proposition from our supreme courtâ€™s holding in State v. Sullivan, 310 S.C. 311, 426 S.E.2d 766 (1993).Â  In Sullivan, the court reiterated the general tenet of applying a specific rule over a general rule.Â  Id. at 314, 426 S.E.2d at 768. Â In Sullivan, the general rule considered was section 18-3-30, which governed appeals in general.Â  The court held because section 22-3-1000 dealt specifically with motions for new trial, rather than appeals in general, section 22-3-1000 prevailed.Â  Id.Â  Because Babbâ€™s motion for new trial was not served on the magistrate until February 19 at the earliest, more than five days after judgment, it was not timely served.Â  Only a timely served motion for a new trial extends the time for filing a notice of appeal. Â See generally Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 15, 602 S.E.2d 772, 775 (2004) (discussing effects of post-trial motions).
Finally, Babb argues the circuit court erred in rejecting her contention that because we have a unified judicial system, the filing of the notice of appeal with the circuit court equates to service on the magistrate.Â  We disagree.Â  Our judicial system is defined as a unified judicial system.Â  S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 1.Â  The magistrate courts are included in this system.Â  State ex rel. McLeod v. Crowe, 272 S.C. 41, 46, 249 S.E.2d 772, 775 (1978).Â  However, section 18-3-30 specifically addresses the burden upon an appellant to perfect an appeal from magistrate court providing:Â  â€œ[t]he appellant shall . . . serve notice of appeal upon the magistrate . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-3-30 (1985).Â  The unification of our court system does not relieve an appellant of the statutory mandate.Â  We find no error.Â  
 
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  Babb argues she filed the motion for new trial on February 19, 2004.Â  For purposes of this appeal, either filing date results in the same disposition.

title: Evans v. SCDPPPS
text:
The South Carolina Court of Appeals


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Maxie Doyal Evans, III, Appellant,
				v.
				South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services, Agents John Doe and Jane Doe, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-245
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed May 22, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Maxie Doyal Evans, III, of Jesup, Georgia,
				pro se, Appellant.Â  
				Deputy Director for Legal Services Teresa Knox, Assistant Chief Legal Counsel J. Benjamin Aplin, and Legal Counsel Tommy Evans, Jr., all of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Maxie Doyal Evans, III, appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order refusing to set aside his parole revocation warrant.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Evans was convicted of safecracking, burglary in the second degree, possession of tools of a crime, and grand larceny.Â  He was paroled on January 4, 2000. Â The South Carolina Parole Board permitted Evansâ€™ parole to be transferred to Georgia pursuant to the Interstate Compact for Adult Offender Supervision (S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 24-21-1100 - 1220) (Rev. 2007). Â While in Georgia, Evans was arrested for possession of a firearm by a felon.Â  He was convicted of the charge and incarcerated in federal prison in Georgia.Â  The South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services (the Department) issued a warrant for Evansâ€™ arrest for various parole violations, including his weapons conviction. Â However, the warrant was not executed. Â Instead, a detainer was filed against Evans pursuant to which the federal prison system agreed to detain Evans upon his release so he could be taken into custody by the Department.Â  Evans was apprised of the existence of the warrant, and he signed an agreement waiving his preliminary hearing on the parole violation charges. Â 
Afterward, Evans began filing complaints with the prison insisting he could not be detained for parole violations by South Carolina authorities after his release from federal prison. Â He believed the agreement he signed was actually a revocation of his parole in South Carolina, as a result of which he was serving his parole revocation concurrently with his federal sentence.Â  Because the warrant and his parole revocation were still outstanding, Evans was not eligible to participate in some federal pre-release programs. Â 
Evans filed a motion with the Richland County circuit court to â€œVacate and Set Asideâ€ his parole violation warrant. Â The circuit court dismissed Evansâ€™ motion, finding the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction over the parole violation warrant and that jurisdiction to determine whether parole has been violated and should be revoked lies with the Department.Â  The court also held that Evans had not been deprived of any constitutional rights. Â Evans then filed a â€œComplaintâ€ against the Department in Richland County circuit court claiming the agency had breached contractual duties owed to him. Â The circuit court construed Evansâ€™ complaint as a motion to reconsider, which it denied. Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The circuit courtâ€™s final order was filed May 25, 2006.Â  The Department argues that Evans filed his notice of appeal on July 27, 2006, which would fall outside the 30 day limitation provided for in South Carolina Appellate Court Rule 203(b).Â  If so, this court is without jurisdiction to hear Evansâ€™ complaint. Â Elam v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 14-15, 602 S.E.2d 772, 775 (2004) (â€œThe requirement of service of the notice of appeal is jurisdictional, i.e., if a party misses the deadline, the appellate court lacks jurisdiction to consider the appeal . . . .â€).Â  Evans contends he received the courtâ€™s order on June 1, 2006 and mailed his notice of appeal to the Department and the court by certified mail on June 29 and 30, respectively.Â  The documents in Evansâ€™ appellate file support his contention and demonstrate that he did everything possible to timely file his notice of appeal.Â  Consequently, we elect to address his claims on the merits.
Evans raises numerous issues in his pro se appeal that in sum and substance amount to two arguments. Â First, he contends that the parole agreement is a contract, and the Department violated the covenant of good faith and fair dealing implicit therein when it did not â€œacceptâ€ his waiver, causing his probation revocation to run concurrent with his federal sentence.Â  He next argues he has been denied procedural due process because his parole violation warrant was not immediately executed and a revocation hearing conducted.
 
First, there is no contractual relationship between the Department and Evans based upon his parole agreement.Â  The extension of parole to an inmate is gratuitous.Â  See State v. De La Cruz, 302 S.C. 13, 16, 393 S.E.2d 184, 186 (1990) (â€œ[T]he ability to obtain parole is a matter of legislative grace.â€).Â  While the offer of parole will no doubt be accepted by most prisoners, there is simply no consideration exchanged between the parties.Â  See Armstrong v. Collins, 366 S.C. 204, 222, 621 S.E.2d 368, 377 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œThe required elements of a contract are an offer, acceptance, and valuable consideration.â€).Â  Because there is no contract formed under such circumstances, the Department could not breach any contractually based duties that Evans contends arose in his favor.
Furthermore, a plain reading of the â€œWaiver of Preliminary Hearingâ€[2] signed by Evans indicates Evans admitted to a violation of his parole and waived his right to a preliminary hearing. Â Such a hearing is held to determine if there is probable cause to believe that the parolee has committed acts that would constitute a violation of parole conditions.Â  See Russell v. Cooper, 263 S.C. 526, 530, 211 S.E.2d 655, 657 (1975).Â  This preliminary hearing is not a final determination and does not result in a decision regarding parole revocation.Â  See Morrissey v. Brewer, 408 U.S. 471, 484-89 (1972) (discussing the â€œtwo important stagesâ€ of parole revocation: Â â€œ(a) Arrest of Parolee and Preliminary Hearingâ€ and â€œ(b) the Revocation Hearingâ€).Â  The waiver does not intimate that Evans forfeited his parole thereby causing the revocation to be served simultaneously with his federal sentence.Â  It simply indicates Evans waived his right to the initial preliminary hearing.Â  To construe the waiver as more is overreaching.
Finally, the United States Supreme Court has made clear that an inmateâ€™s due process rights are not violated under these conditions.Â  In Moody v. Daggett, 429 U.S. 78 (1976), Moody was on parole for a 1962 federal rape charge.Â  Id. at 80. Â He was then convicted for murder.Â  Id.Â  The parole board prepared a parole violation warrant that it did not execute, instead placing a detainer on Moody.Â  Id. at 80-81.Â  The court concluded:Â  â€œThe issue before us here, . . . , is not whether a Morrissey-type[3] hearing will ever be constitutionally required in the present case, but whether a hearing must be held at the present time, before the parolee is taken into custody as a parole violator.Â  We hold that there is no requirement for an immediate hearing.â€Â  Moody, 429 U.S. at 86.Â  Likewise, there is no requirement that Evans receive an immediate hearing or that his parole revocation run concurrently with his federal sentence.Â  

AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  The documentâ€™s full title is â€œOS Waiver of Preliminary Hearing (Form4-7) on Parole or Conditional Release Revocation and Agreement to Return.â€
[3]  Morrissey, 408 U.S. at 488-89, established the minimum requirements for due process with respect to parole revocation:Â  (a) written notice of the claimed violations of parole; (b) disclosure to the parolee of evidence against him; (c) opportunity to be heard in person and to present witnesses and documentary evidence; (d) the right to confront and cross-examine adverse witnesses (unless the hearing officer specifically finds good cause for not allowing confrontation); (e) a neutral and detached hearing body such as a traditional parole board, members of which need not be judicial officers or lawyers; and (f) a written statement by the factfinders as to the evidence relied on and reasons for revoking parole.
