text:
PREHEARING REPORT


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Diana Blue, Appellant,
				v.
				Coastal Carolina University, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-246
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed May 22, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				William I. Diggs, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
				Amanda A. Bailey and Henrietta U. Golding, both of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Diana Blue appeals from the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Coastal Carolina University (University) with regard to her claims of breach of employment contract and violation of the Payment of Wages Act.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
During the calendar year 2004, University solicited applications to fill a position opening designated, â€œAssistant Director of Academic Advising and First Year Programs for Coastal Carolina University.â€Â  Blue submitted a letter of application and went through the interview process.Â  On June 10, 2004, Dr. Ronald R. Ingle, the president of University, sent a letter to Blue stating: 
 

	Upon the recommendation of Dr. Linda Hollandsworth, Director of Advisement and Retention, I am pleased to offer you the position of Assistant Director of First Year Programs and Academic Advising (Student Services Program Coordinator II) at Coastal Carolina University. Â The salary for this position will be $32,500 on a twelve-month basis and the appointment will begin on August 2, 2004.Â  This classified position is subject to state regulations and the University policies as outlined in the Policies and Procedures Manual.
	We feel most fortunate in having an individual with your background and talent joining us at Coastal Carolina University.Â  
	

Blue accepted the offer of employment and reported for work on August 2, 2004.Â  On November 5, 2004, Dr. Linda Hollingsworth notified Blue by letter that her employment â€œwill terminate during [the] probationary period, effective December 31, 2004.â€Â  
 
Asseverating the June 10, 2004 letter established a contract between University and Blue, Blue brought this action alleging a breach of employment contract and seeking the payment of wages called for under the terms of the agreement.Â  It is undisputed that Blue was paid for her employment, including accrued vacation days, through December 31, 2004 and that she performed no services for University following December 31, 2004.Â  University filed a motion for summary judgment.Â  The trial judge granted Universityâ€™s motion for summary judgment holding the plain and ordinary meaning of the language used in the letter did not create a contract of employment for a specified term.[2]Â  The court also found Blue was paid all wages due and granted summary judgment on the issue of wages.Â  This appeal follows. 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 340, 611 S.E.2d 485, 488 (2005).Â  Summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP;Â  Helms Realty, Inc., 363 S.C. at 340, 611 S.E.2d at 488.Â  To determine whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corrections, 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).Â  When plain, palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ, summary judgment should be granted.Â  Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 518, 595 S.E.2d 817, 822 (Ct. App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Blue argues the trial court erred in failing to find the June 10, 2004 letter created a contract of employment for a term of one year.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina has long recognized the doctrine of employment at-will.Â  Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 363 S.C. 460, 471, 611 S.E.2d 905, 910-11 (2005).Â  This doctrine provides that a contract for permanent employment is terminable at the pleasure of either party when unsupported by any consideration other than the employerâ€™s duty to provide compensation in exchange for the employeeâ€™s duty to perform a service or obligation.Â  See Prescott v. Farmers Tel. Coop., Inc., 335 S.C. 330, 334, 516 S.E.2d 923, 925 (1999).Â  This doctrine allows either party to terminate the employment â€œfor any reason or no reasonâ€ without being subject to a claim for breach of contract.Â  Horton v. Darby Elec. Co., Inc., 360 S.C. 58, 67, 599 S.E.2d 456, 460 (2004);Â  Burns v. Universal Health Servs, Inc., 361 S.C 221, 233, 603 S.E.2d 605, 611 (Ct. App. 2004).Â 
 
An employer and employee may contractually alter an at-will employment relationship, and as a result limit the ability of either party to terminate the employment relationship without incurring liability.Â  Id. at 233-34, 603 S.E.2 at 612 (citations omitted).Â  In order to prove the existence of a definite contract of employment, the employee must establish all of the elements of a contract.Â  Prescott, 335 S.C. at 336, 516 S.E.2d at 926.Â  An employment contract must contain the following three elements: 1) a specific offer; 2) communication of that offer to the employee; and 3) performance of job duties in reliance on the offer.Â  Id.
Blue claims the language in the letter, â€œthe salary for this position will be $32,500 on a twelve-month basis and the appointment will begin on August 2, 2004,â€ constituted a specific offer of employment for a twelve-month term at the specified salary.Â  In the alternative, Blue claims the letter creates an ambiguity as to whether University made a specific offer of employment for a twelve-month term, thereby making summary judgment improper.Â  To be binding, an offer of employment must be definite and â€œbe one which is intended of itself to create legal relations on acceptance.â€Â  Id. at 336-37, 516 S.E.2d at 926 (citation omitted).Â  We find Blue has failed to establish Universityâ€™s June 10, 2004 letter was a definite offer of employment such as to alter her at-will employment status.Â  The plain and ordinary meaning of the language used in the letter did not create a term of employment for twelve months; but, rather indicated the salary for the position and the start date of employment.[3]Â   
Blue further argues the trial court erred in granting summary judgment on her claim for damages under the South Carolina Payment of Wages Act.Â  We disagree.
Blue contends Universityâ€™s withholding of wages due to her pursuant to the terms of her employment contract violates the South Carolina Payment of Wages Act and seeks damages under the Act.Â  The Payment of Wages Act is remedial legislation designed to protect working people and assist them in collecting compensation wrongfully withheld.Â  Abraham v. Palmetto Unified Sch. Dist. No. 1, 343 S.C. 36, 50, 538 S.E.2d 656, 664 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Because we have already determined Blue was an at-will employee, subject to termination at the pleasure of University, and there is no dispute as to whether Blue is owed wages for her services prior to termination, the trial court properly granted summary judgment on this issue.
 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] In addition to the plain language used in the letter, the court found a specific reference in the letter, â€œ[t]his classified position is subject to state regulations and the University policies as outlined in the Policies and Procedures Manual,â€ further indicated University did not intend to create a contract of employment for a specified term.Â  State law, regulations, and University policies all provide that a newly hired classified employee must complete a probationary period of twelve monthsâ€™ duration for non-instructional personnel.Â  See, e.g., S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 8-17-310, et. seq., S.C. Code Regs. 19-700 et. seq., Coastal Carolina University Policies and Procedures Manual Sections 1246 et. seq., 1246.02(B), 1227 et seq., 1227.0601, 1247 et. seq., 1247.01(A).Â  Additionally, the state law, regulations, and University policies all provide that an employee that performs unsatisfactorily during the probationary period must be terminated before becoming a covered employee and may not avail herself to any grievance procedures.Â  Id.
[3] Â Both University and the trial court find further reliance for the at-will status of Blue in the letterâ€™s reference to Universityâ€™s Policies and Procedures Manual.Â  Because we find the letter is clear and unambiguous we need not look to the Policies and Procedures Manual for further reliance.Â

title: Tedder v. Dixie Lawn Service
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Jason Tedder, Respondent,
				v.
				Dixie Lawn Service, Inc.,  Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
AFFIRMED

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-249
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed May 22, 2007
Andrew F. Lindemann, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Barry B. George, of Columbia, for Respondents.
PER CURIAM: Â Dixie Lawn Services, Inc. (Dixie) appeals the juryâ€™s verdict finding Dixie vicariously liable for injuries Jason Tedder (Tedder) suffered in a motor vehicle accident.Â  Specifically, Dixie argues the driver, John Fowler, a Dixie employee, was acting outside the scope of his employment at the time of the accident; Tedderâ€™s attorney made inappropriate remarks during closing argument; the trial court erred in admitting medical expenses without evidence of a connection with the accident; and a new trial was warranted because the damages award was excessive.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On August 14, 2001, Tedder and a co-worker were returning to work in a pick-up truck when they were rear-ended by Fowler at approximately one oâ€™clock in the afternoon.Â  Tedderâ€™s head allegedly struck the rear windshield of the truck he occupied.Â 
 
At the time of the accident, Fowler was driving a vehicle owned by Dixie, a business that provided lawn and landscaping services.Â  Fowler was an employee of Dixie and a permissive user of the vehicle.Â  According to Tedder, immediately following the accident Fowler stated he was on his way to work and regretted the accident.Â  On cross-examination, Tedder read a statement from his deposition, quoting Fowler saying, â€œOh, man, Iâ€™m sorry, I was adjusting my radio, I didnâ€™t even see you.â€Â  During the deposition, Tedder did not remember any other statements made by Fowler following the wreck.Â 
 
Tedder brought suit against Dixie.Â  The jury heard testimony from Tedderâ€™s chiropractor, Tedder, and a medical records custodian.Â  Following Tedderâ€™s presentation of evidence, Dixie moved for a directed verdict on the ground Tedder failed to prove Fowler was acting within the scope of his employment at the time of the accident.Â  The trial court relied on three facts when denying the motion: the accident occurred in the middle of the day; Fowler was driving Dixieâ€™s vehicle; and Tedderâ€™s testimony that Fowler said he was on his way to work.Â  The trial court determined it was a jury issue whether Fowler was within the scope of his employment.Â  The jury returned a verdict for Tedder in the amount of $54,927.15.Â 
 
DISCUSSION
I. Scope of Employment
Dixie argues the trial court erred by not directing a verdict or issuing a judgment notwithstanding the verdict because Tedder failed to prove Fowler was within the scope of employment at the time of the accident.Â  We disagree.
 
â€œWhen reviewing the denial of a motion for directed verdict or JNOV, this Court must employ the same standard as the trial court by viewing the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 299-00, 536 S.E.2d 408, 418 (Ct. App. 2000) (citing Steinke v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 520 S.E.2d 142 (1999); Gastineau v. Murphy, 331 S.C. 565, 503 S.E.2d 712 (1998)).Â  The trial court must deny the motions for directed verdict and judgment notwithstanding the verdict when the evidence yields more than one inference.Â  Welch, 342 S.C. at 300, 536 S.E.2d at 418 (citation omitted).

Generally, a master is liable for his servantâ€™s torts when the servant is acting within the scope of employment.Â  See Bolin v. Bostics, 235 S.C. 319, 322, 111 S.E.2d 557, 558 (1959).Â  A servant acts within the scope of employment if the action is reasonably necessary to accomplish the purpose of his employment and the action furthers the masterâ€™s business.Â  Id. (quoting Adams v. S.C. Power Co., 200 S.C. 438, 441, 21 S.E.2d 17, 19 (1942)).
Bolin illustrates the general rule that an employee driving to and from work is usually acting solely for the employeeâ€™s benefit.Â  235 S.C. at 323, 111 S.E.2d at 559.Â  In Bolin, a salesman was driving his own car to his place of business in order to report at the required time.Â  Id. at 321-22, 111 S.E.2d at 558.Â  The court found that the salesmanâ€™s actions did not bring him under special exceptions to the general rule that driving to and from work is outside the scope of employment.Â  Id. at 324, 111 S.E.2d at 559.Â  
 
Conversely, in Hamilton v. Miller, 301 S.C. 45, 47-48, 389 S.E.2d 652, 53-54 (1990), an employeeâ€™s action was found within the scope of Â employment when the employee drove her supervisorâ€™s vehicle to pick up her supervisorâ€™s son from the dentist.Â  Although the employer was an insurance agency, the employer allowed the employee to run errands for her supervisor.Â  Id. at 47, 389 S.E.2d at 653.Â  In determining that the employee was acting within the scope of her employment, the court was persuaded by evidence that the employee was driving the supervisorâ€™s vehicle, the accident occurred at approximately five oâ€™clock in the afternoon during regular office hours, and the employee was being paid her hourly wage at the time of the accident.Â  Id. at 48, 389 S.E.2d at 654.
In this case the accident occurred at approximately one oâ€™clock in the afternoon during regular business hours in the landscaping business.Â  Fowler was driving a vehicle owned by Dixie, was a Dixie employee, and was a permissive user of the vehicle.Â  Tedder testified that, following the accident, Fowler approached him and said, â€œIâ€™m sorry.Â  I was on my way to work and I was adjusting my radio and I never saw you.â€Â  Tedder testified Fowler stated he had not been at work for a few weeks and Dixie would be mad that he wrecked the truck.Â  
 
Given our limited scope of review and the specific facts of this case, the issue of whether Fowler was within the scope of employment was properly submitted to the jury and the juryâ€™s verdict should not be disturbed.Â  Therefore, we hold that the trial court did not err in denying Dixieâ€™s motion for a directed verdict and motion for a judgment not withstanding the verdict based on scope of employment.
II. Closing Arguments
Dixie argues Tedderâ€™s closing argument deprived Dixie of a fair trial and a new trial is warranted.Â  We disagree.
â€œA trial court is allowed broad discretion in dealing with the range and propriety of closing argument to the jury.â€ Â Oâ€™Leary-Payne v. R.R. Hilton Head, II, Inc., 371 S.C. 340, 352, 638 S.E.2d 96, 102 (Ct. App. 2006) (petition for certiorari pending) (citing State v. Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 195-96, 562 S.E.2d 320, 325 (Ct. App. 2002)). Â The trial courtâ€™s rulings regarding content of a closing argument will not ordinarily be disturbed. Â Oâ€™Leary-Payne, 371 S.C. at 352, 638 S.E.2d at 102 (citing State v. Patterson, 324 S.C. 5, 17, 482 S.E.2d 760, 766 (1997)); State v. Copeland, 321 S.C. 318, 324, 468 S.E.2d 620, 624 (1996) (â€œThe trial courtâ€™s discretion will not be overturned absent a showing of an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law that prejudices the defendant.â€). 
 
During Tedderâ€™s closing argument, trial counsel addressed the issue of whether Fowler was, at the time of the accident, actively working for and furthering the interest of Dixie.Â  Throughout closing argument, Tedderâ€™s attorney indicated Dixie could have provided evidence regarding Fowlerâ€™s employment.Â  Dixieâ€™s attorney contemporaneously objected that Tedderâ€™s attorney was shifting the burden of proof.Â  The trial court responded: â€œThey [Dixie] donâ€™t have the burden of proof.Â  He [Tedder] does.Â  But he [Tedder] can argue conjecture, and so forth, and circumstantial evidence.â€Â Â Â  
 
After further objection from Dixie, the trial court again instructed the jury that Dixie did not have the burden of proof and informed Tedderâ€™s attorney the court would require him to sit down if he again referenced what Dixie did or did not do.Â  Following another comment, Dixieâ€™s attorney objected again, and the trial court instructed Tedderâ€™s attorney to sit down.Â  Following closing arguments, the trial court repeatedly instructed the jury that Tedder, as the plaintiff, had the burden of proof.Â  
 

	The trial court properly used discretion to cure any possible confusion concerning the burden of proof.Â  Thus, the denial of Dixieâ€™s motion for a new trial was not an abuse of discretion. 
	

III. Admission of Medical Bills
Dixie argues the trial court erred in admitting evidence of medical bills incurred by Tedder, when Tedderâ€™s testimony regarding the bills was the only evidence linking the bills and the accident.Â  We disagree.
The admissibility of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error prejudicing the defendant.Â  Wright v. Craft, 371, S.C. 1, ___, 640 S.E.2d 486, 503 (Ct. App. 2006) (citing State v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 77, 538 S.E.2d 257, 263 (Ct. App. 2000)). Â â€œIf the facts and circumstances proved give rise to a reasonable inference of a causal connection between a plaintiffâ€™s present condition and the earlier accident, the absence of medical testimony need not be conclusive.â€Â  Howle v. PYA/Monarch, Inc., 288 S.C. 586, 596, 344 S.E.2d 157, 162 (Ct. App. 1986) (citing Gambrell v. Burleson, 252 S.C. 98, 165 S.E.2d 622 (1969); Grice v. Dickerson, Inc., 241 S.C. 225, 127 S.E.2d 722 (1962)).Â  
 
In Howle, the Plaintiff testified prior to the accident she did not have vision problems and following the accident she did have vision problems.Â  288 S.C. at 597, 344 S.E.2d at 162.Â  As to emotional problems, the Plaintiff testified she was never hospitalized for emotional problems prior to the accident, while doctors testified she was upset and depressed following the accident.Â  Id. at 597, 344 S.E.2d at 163.Â  We held that, although the Plaintiff might have presented additional testimony to establish the casual connection between the accident and her visual and emotional problems, a common sense connection that was more than â€œmere temporal sequenceâ€ existed to support her claim.Â  Id.Â  
 

In this case, a chiropractor testified Tedder would not have problems with his neck if the accident had not occurred.Â  During a description of the accident, Tedder asserted that his head was thrown into the truckâ€™s rear windshield.Â  He distinguished prior injuries as unrelated to his current neck pain.Â  Tedder stated he would not have incurred the medical expenses if the accident had not occurred. 
 
Dixie objected to admission of the medical bills for lack of foundation, and the trial court made the following explanatory statement to the jury:

	The fact that a medical bill is presented certainly indicates that the bill was incurred.Â  Okay, the Plaintiff [Tedder] has the burden of showing that it was incurred as a direct result of the particular accident.Â  Thatâ€™s all.Â 
	
	It would be better to have somebody from the medical center to say that was the bill, but, you know, it is in.Â  Yâ€™all have heard the facts.Â  You will decide whether this bill and the other bills that are going to come in arose out of this accident or not.Â  
	

Evidence points to more than a mere temporal sequence connecting the medical bills with the accident.Â  Certainly, testimony from a physician linking the bills and the accident would have strengthened Tedderâ€™s case, but this failure does not prevent the medical bills from being properly admitted into evidence.Â  Thus, based on the reasonable inference of their nexus to the accident, the trial court did not err in admitting the medical bills.
IV. New Trial 
Dixie argues the trial court erred in failing to grant a new trial absolute or a new trial nisi due to the alleged excessiveness of the verdict.Â  We disagree.
â€œA new trial absolute should be granted only if the verdict is so grossly excessive that it shocks the conscience of the court and clearly indicates the amount of the verdict was the â€˜result of caprice, passion, prejudice, partiality, corruption, or other improper motives.â€™ â€ Wright v. Craft, 372 S.C. 1, __, 640 S.E.2d 486, 505 (Ct. App. 2006) (quoting Smalls v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Educ., 339 S.C. 208, 215, 528 S.E.2d 682, 686 (Ct. App. 2000)).Â  For a new trial absolute to be warranted, the verdict must be so grossly excessive as to clearly indicate the influence of an improper jury motive. Â Wright, 372 S.C. at __, 640 S.E.2d at 505 (citation omitted). Â A trial courtâ€™s failure to grant a new trial absolute will be reversed if the courtâ€™s discretion was abused. Id. at __, 640 S.E.2d at 505 (citations omitted).
A new trial nisi is only warranted when compelling reasons justify invading the juryâ€™s province in awarding its verdict.Â  Bailey v. Peacock, 318 S.C. 13, 14, 455 S.E.2d 690, 691 (1995); Pelican Bldg. Centers of Horry-Georgetown, Inc. v. Dutton, 311 S.C. 56, 61, 427 S.E.2d 673, 675-76 (1993).Â  Absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law, the trial courtâ€™s decision to deny a motion for a new trial nisi will not be disturbed upon review of the trial record.Â  Bailey, 318 S.C. at 14, 455 S.E.2d at 691.Â  
 
In the case at hand, Tedderâ€™s complaint requested relief of $70,000.00.Â  Tedderâ€™s medical bills totaled $4,927.15.Â  Total recovery was not achieved according to Tedderâ€™s chiropractor.Â  Tedder testified he suffers from neck pain twenty-four hours a day and experiences spells of dizziness and nausea.Â  Tedder will likely continue to suffer from injuries related to the accident.Â  Thus, the juryâ€™s verdict does not shock the conscience and is within the range provided in the record.Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s denial of Dixieâ€™s motion for a new trial absolute or a new trial nisi was not an abuse of discretion.
CONCLUSION
Based on the evidence presented, the trial court properly submitted to the jury the issue of whether Fowler was acting within the scope of his employment.Â  The trial court cured any improper burden shifting in Tedderâ€™s closing argument and reinforced those corrections as he charged the jury.Â  Admission of medical bills that had a reasonable causal connection with the accident was not an abuse of discretion.Â  The trial court did not err by denying Dixieâ€™s motions for a new trial absolute and a new trial nisi because the verdict was consistent with evidence in the record.
Accordingly, the juryâ€™s verdict awarding damages in the amount of $54,927.15 and the trial courtâ€™s rulings are 
 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ken Buffington, Louis Shepard, Mary E. Williams, Brian Meece and Shirley Jones, Respondents,
				v.
				T.O.E Enterprises, A South Carolina General Partnership and T.O.E. Residential, LLC, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Pickens County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-252
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed May 24, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Woodrow Grady Jordan, of Easley, for Appellants.
				Thomas Bailey Smith, of Easley, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  T.O.E. Enterprises and T.O.E. Residential, LLC (collectively T.O.E.) appeal the trial courtâ€™s order permanently enjoining T.O.E. from using two lots for commercial purposes in violation of restrictive covenants.Â  T.O.E argues the trial court erred by not balancing the equities of the parties and in not finding conditions had changed sufficiently so as to nullify the restrictive covenants.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Ken Buffington, Louis Sheppard, Mary Williams, Brian Meece, and Shirley Jones (collectively Residents) owned lots in the Forest Acres Subdivision in Easley when this action was commenced.Â  The Forest Acres Subdivision is shown on a plat recorded on October 3, 1960. Restrictive covenants for the subdivision were also recorded on October 3, 1960. The restrictive covenants state â€œ[n]o lot shall be used except for residential purposes.â€ However, multiple lots are specifically excluded from the operation of the covenants. In addition, all lots marked â€œReservedâ€ on the plat are unaffected by the covenants.  The parties agreed the covenants apply to only 62 of the 110 lots in the subdivision.Â 
 
TOE owns a Toyota dealership that borders Forest Acres Subdivision.  Between 2003 and 2004, it purchased a portion of lot 9, as well as lots 10, 11, and 12 in the subdivision.  Moreover, TOE leases the remainder of lot 9.Â  A portion of lot 9 is marked reserved on the plat, lots 10 and 12 are included in the covenants, and lot 11 is specifically excluded from the covenants. Â  TOE acquired these lots to expand the parking lot for its dealership and has already paved all of lot 9. Â  
 
Residents brought a declaratory judgment action seeking a declaration of their rights, as well as an order permanently enjoining T.O.E. from using lots 9, 10, or 12 for non-residential purposes. The trial court found that the restrictive covenants did not apply to lot 9 because the lot was marked "reserved" on the plat. Additionally, the trial court concluded T.O.E failed to offer sufficient evidence of changed conditions to warrant invalidating the covenants. Ultimately, the trial court permanently enjoined T.O.E from using lots 10 and 12 for non-residential purposes.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA declaratory judgment action is neither legal nor equitable in nature, but it takes on the tenor of the underlying action.â€Â  Seabrook Island Prop. Owners Assâ€™n v. Marshland Trust, Inc., 358 S.C. 655, 661, 596 S.E.2d 380, 382-83 (Ct. App. 2004) (citation omitted). Â â€œAn action to enforce restrictive covenants by injunction is in equity.â€ S.C. Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 622, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302 (2001) (citing Taylor v. Lindsey, 332 S.C. 1, 3 n.2, 498 S.E.2d 862, 864 n.2 (1998)).Â  
 
When reviewing an action tried by a judge alone in equity, the appellate court â€œhas jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its views of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976) (citation omitted).Â  Despite this broad scope of review, an appellate court should not ignore the findings of the trial court because the trial judge was in a better position to evaluate witness credibility.Â  Seabrook Island, 358 S.C. at 661, 596 S.E.2d at 383.Â  Although, a party may bring a declaratory judgment action to invalidate a restrictive covenant based on a change of conditions, the party bringing the action bears the burden of proof by a preponderance of the evidence.Â  Menne v. Keowee Key Prop. Owners Assoc, Inc., 368 S.C. 557, 564, 629 S.E. 2d 690, 694 (Ct. App. 2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS 
I.  Balancing the Equities of the Parties
T.O.E. argues the trial court erred by failing to balance the equities in favor of T.O.E.Â  We disagree.
An injunction, as all equitable remedies, is granted as a matter of sound judicial discretion; however, the right of the plaintiff to an injunction in the enforcement of a restrictive covenant traditionally receives special treatment.Â  See Houck v. Rivers, 316 S.C. 414, 418, 450 S.E.2d 106, 109 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  
 
â€œThe rules applicable to the construction of contracts are applicable to the construction of covenants in deeds.â€Â  Id. at 416, 450 S.E.2d at 108 (citation omitted).Â  â€œAs voluntary contracts, restrictive covenants will be enforced unless they are indefinite or contravene public policy.â€Â  Id. (citation omitted).Â  â€œCovenants that restrict the free use of property must be strictly construed against limitations upon the propertyâ€™s free use.â€ Â Hyer v. McRee, 306 S.C. 210, 212, 410 S.E.2d 604, 605 (Ct. App. 1991) (citation omitted). Further, where doubt exists, the doubt must be resolved in favor of the free use of the property.Â  Id.Â  
 
Although, T.O.E. and Residents agree that the covenants apply to lots 10 and 12, T.O.E. argues the trial court erred in not balancing the equities of the parties, and thereby, invalidating the covenantsâ€™ application to those lots.Â  We acknowledge that Siau v. Kassel, 369 S.C. 631, 641, 632 S.E.2d 888, 893 (Ct. App. 2006), states that based on Houck, a trial court is not required to balance the equities of the parties before enforcing restrictive covenants.Â  However, even were we to balance the equities in this case, equity clearly favors Residents. 
 
In arguing that the equities favor terminating the restrictive covenants, T.O.E. claims it will have to relocate its dealership due to pressure from Toyota ifÂ  itÂ  is not allowed to use the land in question for parking. T.O.E. presented testimony that it has already spent over $700,000 on the property.Â  Further, T.O.E. points to the presence of commercial buildings within the subdivision: a motel, a bowling alley, a furniture store, and a Chinese restaurant.
 
However, these commercial buildings are on lots in the subdivision and an area excluded from the restrictive covenants. Moreover, Residents assert that prior to the lawsuit that they did not realize the commercial buildings were part of the subdivision.Â 
 
The evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s conclusion that while T.O.E. has presented evidence of a potential financial loss, the Residents loss of the character of their subdivision outweighs T.O.E.â€™s financial concerns.Â  See Houck, 316 S.C. at 419, 450 S.E.2d at 109 (stating that a restrictive covenant will be enforced irrespective of the financial damage potentially caused by enforcement of the covenant). SeeÂ­ Also Circle Square Company v. Atlantis Development Company, 267 S.C. 618, 630, 230 S.E. 2d 704, 709 (1976) (Equity will enforce restrictive covenants made for the benefit of an ownerâ€™s land if they remain of substantial value, even though, because of changed conditions, hardship will be visited on the servient estate). Accordingly, the trial court did not err in enforcing the covenants inasmuch as the equities clearly favor the enforcement of the restrictive covenants.
II.  Changed Conditions
T.O.E. argues the trial court erred by not finding that changed conditions do not exist to the extent to require nullification of the restrictive covenants.Â  We disagree.
â€œTo defeat enforcement of covenants restricting the use of land, changed conditions must be so radical as to practically destroy the essential objects and purposes of the covenants.â€Â  Shipyard Property Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n v. Mangiaracina, 307 S.C. 299, 308, 414 S.E.2d 795, 801 (Ct. App. 1992) (citation omitted); see also Inabinet v. Booe, 262 S.C. 81, 84, 202 S.E.2d 643, 645 (1974). Â This change in conditions is also described as such Â a â€œchange in the character of the neighborhood as to render the enforcement of the covenant valueless to the covenantee and oppressive and unreasonable as to the covenantor.â€Â  Dunlap v. Beaty, 239 S.C. 196, 209, 122 S.E.2d 9, 15-16 (1961).
Again, T.O.E. presented evidence of the existence of a motel, a bowling alley, a furniture store, and a Chinese restaurant within the subdivision. However, these commercial buildings existed in areas specifically excluded from the restrictive covenants and apparently within the scheme of the subdivisionâ€™s planned development. This conclusion is buttressed by the fact that Residents did not even realize these areas were part of their subdivision. Therefore, the plan of the subdivision and restrictive covenants have, in fact, worked as designed for over 40 years.Â  The commercial areas were allowed to exist, but only on specified lots, and the rest of the lots enjoyed a typical subdivision appearance.Â  Thus, T.O.E has not carried its burden of showing that conditions in the subdivision have changed to the extent that the covenants no longer served the purpose for which they were recorded.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
 
AFFIRMED.

PER CURIAM: Phillip Miller appeals from his conviction for murder, arguing the trial court erred in failing to charge the jury on voluntary manslaughter.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Ernest Aiken, Jr., was shot and killed on April 28, 2003.Â  Police arrested Miller for the crime, and three eyewitnesses testified against Miller at trial.Â  According to two of the witnesses, the victim had punched Miller prior to being shot.Â  Based on this evidence, the State requested the jury be charged on voluntary manslaughter.Â  Defense counsel objected to this lesser-included charge.Â  With counselâ€™s permission, the trial court engaged in a colloquy with Miller explaining to Miller his right to have the lesser-included crime charged and the different penalties each crime carried.Â  Miller assured the trial court that he and his counsel had discussed â€œthose kinds of thingsâ€ and after those discussions, Miller decided that he did not want a jury instruction on voluntary manslaughter.Â 
 
Pursuant to Millerâ€™s wishes, the trial court did not charge the jury on voluntary manslaughter.Â  The jury convicted him of murder, and he was sentenced to thirty years in prison.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Miller argues the trial court erred by refusing to charge the jury on voluntary manslaughter because there was evidence the victim had punched Miller before getting shot.Â  Specifically, Miller argues that neither the defense nor the solicitor should be allowed to insist that an instruction on a lesser-included offense not be given where it is undisputed there is evidence of that lesser-included offense.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina appellate courts do not follow the plain error rule.Â  See State v. Vanderbilt, 287 S.C. 597, 598, 340 S.E.2d 543, 543-44 (1986) (â€œIssues not properly preserved at trial may not be raised for the first time on appeal.â€) overruling State v. Griffin, 129 S.C. 200, 124 S.E. 81 (1924) (holding that the supreme court will take notice, on defendantâ€™s behalf, of an error in the admission of evidence apparent on the record even though no objection was made). Even in death penalty cases, our supreme court only reviews cases for preserved errors.Â  See State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 60-71, 406 S.E.2d 315, 323-29 (1991) (abolishing in favorem vitae review in capital cases).Â  Furthermore, case law clearly states that an issue cannot be raised on appeal even though another party objects. Â State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 123, 481 S.E.2d 118, 124 (1997) (finding issues not preserved where defendant failed to join in co-defendantâ€™s objections).
Here, not only did Miller make no objection to the manslaughter charge, he specifically requested that no such charge be given. See State v. Chasteen, 242 S.C. 198, 130 S.E.2d 473 (1963) (holding that the defendant could not complain of an error he invited). Accordingly, he cannot now complain that the charge was not given.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Frank M. Marvin, Respondent,
				v.
				Frances R. Pritchett, M.D., Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-In-Equity
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-255
Heard May 7, 2007 â€“ Filed May 24, 2007Â Â Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Ellis R. Lesemann, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				G. Thomas Hill, of Ravenel, Joseph K. Qualey, of Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Frances Pritchett appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s decision ordering a partition by sale instead of adopting the Report of the Commissioners, which recommended a partition in kind.Â  We reverse and remand.
I.
In the 1940s, when Frank Marvin was a child, his parents owned a large tract of property adjacent to the TooGooDoo Creek located in the town of Hollywood in Charleston County.Â  In the mid 1960s, Marvinâ€™s parents sold the property to Buist Hanahan.Â  In the late 1960s, Hanahan also purchased a smaller interior tract.Â  In the mid 1970s, Hanahan offered to sell the entire 235 acre tract (the Property) to Marvin.Â  The Property was once a part of the Ripponton Plantation and was known as â€œSummer Houseâ€ and also â€œWalnut Hill.â€Â  Marvin was unable to purchase the Property alone and asked his friend William Woodward to join him in acquiring the Property.Â  Woodward agreed, and he and his wife, Frances Pritchett, contributed half of the money for the purchase.Â  Later, Pritchett and Woodward divorced, and Pritchett acquired their half-interest in the Property.Â 
 
In 2001, because of Pritchett and Marvinâ€™s inability to agree as to how the Property would be managed, Marvin filed a complaint requesting the partition of the Property in kind or, in the alternative, for the public sale of the Property.Â  The matter was referred to a master-in-equity.Â  On May 13, 2003, the master issued a writ of partition appointing five commissioners.Â  On October 30, 2003, the master issued an order extending the time for the commissionersâ€™ report.Â  On March 19, 2004, the master executed an order by consent of all parties to reduce the number of commissioners from five to three.Â  On the same day, the three commissioners submitted the Report of Commissioners (the Report), which recommends partition in kind.Â  The Report concludes partition in kind is possible and practical and proposes dividing the property into two parcels of equal value.Â  According to the Report, Marvin would receive the Northeastern tract, which contained forty percent of the Property, and Pritchett would receive the Southeastern tract, which contained sixty percent of the Property.Â  To accomplish an overall equal division in terms of value, the unique characteristics of the Property required an unequal division in terms of acreage.[1]Â  
 
On March 31, 2004, Marvin submitted objections to the Report.Â  On April 13, 2003, Commissioner John Thomas submitted a Minority Report of Commissioners and Pritchett submitted an affidavit in favor of the Report.Â  On November 17, 2004, a consent order for continuance was filed.Â  On January 19, 2005, the master issued an order of temporary remand to the partition commission ordering the commissioners to assess values to the two partitioned parcels.Â  
 
On March 7, 2005, the master held a hearing regarding the matter at which Commissioner Kenneth Krawcheck and Commissioner Thomas both of whom testified regarding their respective opinion on the partition of the Property.Â  On April 28, 2005, the master conducted an additional hearing at which Pritchett, Marvin, Commissioner Walton Flowers, and experts for both sides testified.Â 
 
At the conclusion of the witness testimony, the master made an oral ruling that he would reject the Report but granted the parties sixty days to negotiate a buyout before the master would sell the Property at a judicial sale.Â  On January 4, 2006, the master entered an order rejecting the Report, finding it â€œerroneous, unfair, unjust and inequitableâ€ for failing to: (1) place a monetary value on the property beyond a 2000 appraisal; (2) provide for â€œoweltyâ€[2] because of the discrepancy in the sizes of the two parcels; (3) determine the specific acreage sizes for the proposed partition of land; and (4) make findings as to the equitable division of the property other than the conclusory decision that the division was fair and equitable.Â  The master ordered a public sale of the Property. Â This appeal follows.
II.
An action for partition is equitable in nature.Â  Wilson v. McGuire, 320 S.C. 137, 140-41, 463 S.E.2d 614, 616 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œIn an appeal of an equitable action tried before a Master authorized to enter final judgment, this court must review the entire record and make its own findings of fact in accordance with the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Ellis v. Smith Grading & Paving, Inc., 294 S.C. 470, 473, 366 S.E.2d 12, 14 (Ct. App. 1988).
III.
Pritchett contends the master erred in failing to adopt the Report and ordering a partition by sale.Â  First, Pritchett argues the master did not follow the proper standard of review because the evidence does not show the Report is â€œerroneous, unfair, unjust, and inequitable.â€Â  Further, Pritchett maintains the master erred by ordering the disfavored remedy of public sale when the greater weight of the evidence shows the Property can be divided in kind and the master did not find that partition in kind was not practicable or expedient. Â We agree. 
 
A partition procedure must be fair and equitable to all parties of the action.Â  Zimmerman v. Marsh, 365 S.C. 383, 386, 618 S.E.2d 898, 900 (2005).Â  Partition in kind is preferred over a judicial sale of the property. Â Cox v. Frierson, 316 S.C. 469, 470, 451 S.E.2d 392, 393 (1994); see also Pinckney v. Atkins, 317 S.C. 340, 345, 454 S.E.2d 339, 342 (Ct. App. 1995) (finding partition in kind is favored when it can be fairly made without manifest injury to all co-tenants).Â  The party seeking partition by sale carries the burden of showing partition in kind is not practicable or expedient.Â  Anderson v. Anderson, 299 S.C. 110, 114, 382 S.E.2d 897, 899 (1989).Â  In partition proceedings, the court may order the sale of the property and a division of the proceeds to the parties when a partition cannot be fairly and equally made.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-61-100 (2005).Â  

The return of a majority of the commissioners may not be rejected unless the division is clearly shown to be erroneous, unfair, unjust and inequitable.Â  Wilson v. McGuire, 320 S.C. 137, 142, 463 S.E.2d 614, 617 (Ct. App. 1995). Â In order to overturn the valuation made by the commissioners in partition, the valuation must be shown to be â€œso grossly incorrect and unequal as to justify an inference that the commissioners acted from an unfair and improper motive.â€Â  Parrott v. Barrett, 81 S.C. 255, 260, 62 S.E. 241, 242 (1908).
The master stated the Report is erroneous, unfair, unjust, and inequitable but did not make any specific findings regarding what makes it so.Â  The master focuses on the fact that the Report does not provide any specific values of the parcels.Â  In Wilson, 320 S.C. at 142, 463 S.E.2d at 617, this court found the trial courtâ€™s criticisms concerned the value of the allocated parcels, not the feasibility of dividing the tract in-kind, and we found no competent evidence in the record that any tracts were less valuable than others.Â  
 
Here, although the Report does not specify monetary values for the individual parcels, it does provide the two parcels are equal in value.Â  The Report proposes to divide the Property â€œsixty-fortyâ€ to achieve the very thing the master says the Report is lackingâ€”an equality of value.Â  According to the commissioners, because of the topography of the property, a sixty-forty percent division ensures that each party will have an equal share.Â  Certainly, the commissioners were in a good position to make this division.Â  These commissioners were chosen by the parties and the master for their unique expertise not only in real estate, but particularly real estate in this area.Â  In fact, the parties hired Commissioner Flowers in 2000 to appraise the Property.Â  Accordingly, Flowers was intimately familiar with the unique characteristics of this land and the factors that would indicate its value.Â  With these things in mind, we conclude a monetary value was not necessary for the commissioners to divide the Property equally among the parties.
Â It is also important to note that Marvin has not provided any evidence in monetary terms of a disparity between the parcels as divided by the Commission.Â  Although Marvinâ€™s expert, Tommy Harnett, testified the parcels are not equal based on the factors considered by the Commission, he maintained if the Property were divided, the master should adopt the Reportâ€™s division.Â  Pritchettâ€™s expert, Michael Robinson, testified that the two parcels are equal in value.Â  Based on our examination of the Report and the evidence contained in the record, we do not find the Report erroneous, unfair, unjust, and inequitable or so grossly incorrect and unequal as to justify interference.Â  
 
Moreover, for the master to order partition by sale, the master must find partition in kind is not practicable or expedient.Â  The burden is on the party seeking partition by sale to show partition in kind is not practicable or expedient, which Marvin has not shown here.Â  In fact, the master stated, â€œIâ€™m not sure that the partition in kind is not practicable or expedientâ€ and â€œI have no doubt this property can be subdivided under any stretch of the imagination.Â  Itâ€™s 235 acres.Â  Iâ€™m certain it can be divided.â€Â  See Wilson, 320 S.C. at 142, 463 S.E.2d at 617 (â€œ[E]ven if the trial court had a reasonable basis to believe the appellantsâ€™ parcels were more valuable than other parcels, the more appropriate course would have been to recommit the matter to the commissioners to adjust the acreage to be received by the appellants or to have the appellants account for the difference in value by a cash payment and/or deduction from their share of the home place sale proceeds.â€).Â  The division of the Property proposed by the Report is actually very similar to the division Marvin submitted.Â  The evidence does not establish that the parcels are unequal or that the Report is â€œerroneous, unfair, unjust, and inequitable.â€Â  Accordingly, the master should have confirmed the Report.
IV.
The master abused his discretion in rejecting the Report, and the masterâ€™s order is reversed.Â  We remand for entry of judgment in accordance with the Report.
REVERSED and REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] The unique characteristics include the amount of water frontage, the old homestead site, the amount of marshland, and a drainage easement.Â 
 
[2] Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary defines â€œoweltyâ€ as â€œequality as achieved by a compensatory sum of money given after an exchange of parcels of land having different values or after an unequal partition of real property.â€Â  1130 (7th ed. 1999).

text:

					Minors under the age of 18.

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-256
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed May 24, 2007Â

				Timothy C. Merrell, of Seneca, for Appellant.

PER CURIAM:Â  In this family court action, Kenneth Olson (Father) appeals the family courtâ€™s order terminating his parental rights.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
 
FACTS
Father is the biological father of G. N.-F. (Child). This appeal arises from the family courtâ€™s termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights on June 1, 2006, for the following statutory grounds: (1) Child has been out of the home for six months and Father has failed to visit Child; and (2) Child has been out of the home and Father failed to support Child for a period of six months prior to the commencement of the termination of parental rights (TPR) proceedings.Â 
 
Child was born on February 4, 1997, and resided with his mother until the Department of Social Services (DSS) took him into custody on July 17, 2002. At the time, DSS was unaware of Fatherâ€™s identity and believed someone else was Childâ€™s father.Â 
 
On September 8, 2004, DSS instituted this action seeking termination of parental rights and named Father, a Minnesota resident, as defendant.Â  Father submitted to a paternity test, which revealed he was Childâ€™s father.Â  While the TPR action was pending, Heidi Shustarich, the biological aunt of another child involved in the case who is Childâ€™s brother and a resident of Minnesota, filed a third-party petition requesting custody of her biological nephew and Child.Â  On October 10, 2005, the family court ordered the two children continue residing with Shustarich but custody remain with DSS.Â  Additionally, the family court ordered that Father not have visitation with Child because Child was unaware of Fatherâ€™s existence; however, the family court noted Father could â€œfile any appropriate pleadings and/or motions in the matter and take any appropriate action.â€Â  Further, the order provided, â€œthis [c]ourt will not issue a formal order that [Father] pay child support for the minor child . . . .Â  This [o]rder does not relieve [Father] of any moral and/or legal obligation of child support.â€Â 
 
During the TPR hearing on May 9, 2006, Father testified he did not seek visitation because he did not know where Child was until October of the previous year.Â  He stated the family court ordered he could not have any visitation with child.Â  He also testified Shustarichâ€™s residence where Child resided was three blocks away from him, but he still did not see Child.Â 
 
As to paying child support, he testified he wanted to pay, but he was â€œnot given any of [his] God-given rights to see this child.â€Â  Further, he stated the court never ordered him to pay child support and DSS asked him only once, in November 2004, to submit a financial report.Â 
 
Father testified he sometimes babysat Child when Child was an infant.Â  He explained Childâ€™s mother asked him to watch Child for three days but did not return for a week.Â  At that point, he â€œset the rule down . . . [that she] prove the child is mine or please do not bother me anymore because I have [another] child that I need to take care of.â€Â  He testified he never heard from either Child nor his mother until this action.Â  
 
Paula Achenbach, Childâ€™s therapist, testified she believed even if Child met Father, Child could not live with Father.Â  She stated Child was in a pre-adoptive home and it would make his reactive attachment disorder worse.Â  
 
Denise Hudson, a foster care worker for DSS, testified she sent a treatment plan to Father.Â  The treatment plan provided Father have a psychological evaluation, attend anger management and parenting classes, and maintain employment as well as clean and stable housing.Â  She also testified there was a six month period after Father received the results of the paternity test in February of 2005, but before the family court ordered no visitation; however, Father did not visit Child.
 
Following the hearing, the family court found, pursuant to section 20-7-1572(3) and (4) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), Child had been removed from Fatherâ€™s home for more than six months, and Father failed to visit or support Child.Â  The family court also found termination to be in Childâ€™s best interest and, therefore, terminated Fatherâ€™s parental rights.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a TPR case, â€œthe appellate court has jurisdiction to examine the entire record to determine the facts in accordance with its own view of the evidence.â€ Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Richland County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Earles, 330 S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 866 (1998)).Â  In our examination, the best interest of the child is our paramount consideration.Â  Roe, 353 S.C. at 579, 578 S.E.2d at 735.Â  Additionally, the grounds for TPR must be proved by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 747-48 (1982) (holding â€œ[b]efore a State may sever completely and irrevocably the rights of parents in their natural child, due process requires that the State support its allegations by at least clear and convincing evidenceâ€)).Â  â€œOur broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings below or ignore the fact the trial judge was in a better position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996)).
LAW/ANALYSIS

Father argues the family court erred by terminating his parental rights for failure to visit Child.Â  Specifically, Father argues Section 20-7-1572(3) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) provides a TPR proceeding may be commenced if a child has lived outside the home for six months and the parent has willfully failed to visit â€œbut it must be shown that the parent was not prevented from visiting by the party having custody or by court order.â€Â Â  He contends a court order prevented him from visiting Child.Â  We disagree.
Section 20-7-1572 governs actions for TPR in South Carolina and provides â€œ[t]he family court may order termination of parental rights upon a finding of one or more of the [statutory] grounds and a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child.â€Â  In this case, the family court found termination was proper because Father failed to visit Child for a period of six months after removal.
Although the October 2005 order provided for no visitation between Father and Child, the order did state Father could seek visitation by filing the appropriate pleadings or motions.Â  Father did not take any affirmative action to see Child.Â  Â Further, by Fatherâ€™s own admission, he definitively knew he was Childâ€™s father in February 2005, but did not seek any visitation with Child.Â  Therefore, from February until the family court entered its order on October 10, 2005, Father could have attempted to gain visitation with Child but did not do so.[2]Â  Accordingly, the record supports the family courtâ€™s finding that Father willfully failed to visit Child.[3]
Furthermore, we find evidence in the record supports the family courtâ€™s finding that TPR is in the best interest of Child.Â Â  Child is in a pre-adoptive home with his half-sibling, and his foster parents intend to adopt Child once he is freed for adoption.Â  Childâ€™s therapist testified Fatherâ€™s parental rights should be terminated so Child will have stability in his life.Â  Additionally, Father knew he could have been Childâ€™s father but did nothing to establish any contact for almost ten years.Â 
 
Accordingly, the order of the family court is  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, J., and CURETON, A.J.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The hearing occurred on August 30, 2005, and it is unclear from the record if the family court ordered no visitation at this time or if no visitation was mandated by the October order.Â  However, even if no visitation was ordered in August, six months elapsed from when paternity was established on February 15 until August 30.Â  
 
[3] Because we find one of the statutory grounds for termination was met, we need not address the other grounds.Â  See Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Pritchett, 296 S.C. 517, 519, 374 S.E.2d 500, 501 (Ct. App. 1988).
